agency_name: Alabama Department of Labor
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in wages in any calendar quarter or one worker employed on at least 20 different weeks in a year; household employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers become liable when cash wages reach $20,000 in a quarter or when 10 or more workers are employed for 20 weeks; nonprofits (501(c)(3)) become liable with four or more workers for 20 weeks
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one worker (general); 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employment; 20 weeks with four or more workers for nonprofits
withholding_threshold_description: Employers with employees working in Alabama must register for a withholding tax account and withhold Alabama income tax from those employees, even when Alabama residents work out of state; registration is done through My Alabama Taxes
typical_processing_time: Registrations submitted via the eGov portal typically receive an unemployment account number within days; paper Form SR‑2 applications may take several weeks. Withholding registration via My Alabama Taxes is processed online (time varies).
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal name and trade name of the business
Business physical and mailing addresses and phone number
Entity type and date employing workers began
Date of first payroll and total wages paid in the quarter
Names, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners/officers
Whether the business acquired another business or changed form of organization
filing_methods: Online via the Alabama Department of Labor eGov Employer Registration (Form SR‑2) for state unemployment insurance
Paper Form SR‑2 mailed to the Status Unit
Withholding registration via My Alabama Taxes (online)
confirmation_proof: Unemployment insurance account number issued by the Department of Labor and confirmation email/letter; withholding registration provides an account number beginning with “R”
source_notes: Alabama UC Employer information on liability and registration; eGov registration portal description; Alabama Department of Revenue withholding account requirement

agency_name: Alaska Department of Labor and Workforce Development – Employment Security Division
ui_wage_threshold_text: Alaska covers virtually all employers. Any person or business that hires one or more individuals to perform services for any portion of a day is an employer liable for unemployment insurance tax. There is no minimum wage threshold. Nonprofit organizations exempt under IRC 501(c)(3) become liable when they pay an individual $250 or more in a calendar quarter or employ four or more individuals for some portion of a day in each of 20 weeks in a calendar year
ui_threshold_weeks_text: General employers become liable as soon as one worker performs services; there is no minimum number of weeks. Nonprofit employers become liable when they employ four or more workers for some portion of a day in each of 20 weeks in the current or preceding calendar year
withholding_threshold_description: Alaska has no state personal income tax. Employers do not register for state income tax withholding; they only register for unemployment insurance (employment security tax).
typical_processing_time: Employers who register online via TaxWeb receive an Employer Account Number and coverage determination letter by mail. The letter is typically mailed within several business days to a couple of weeks, depending on the season.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Business legal name and mailing address
Business phone/fax numbers and email address
Entity type (e.g., corporation, LLC, sole proprietor)
Date you will first pay wages to employees
Responsible party or owner/officer names and contact information
filing_methods: Online via the Alaska Employment Security Tax (TaxWeb) system through myAlaska
By mail using the Employer Registration Form (available from the Employment Security Tax office)
In person at a Field Tax Office of the Alaska Department of Labor and Workforce Development
confirmation_proof: Employer account number and coverage determination letter (blue Notice to Employees) mailed by the Alaska Department of Labor after registration
source_notes: Information obtained from the Alaska Employment Security Tax Handbook (updated April 2024) describing who is an employer and how to establish an account; Alaska Department of Labor TaxWeb FAQ listing required information for registration

notes: Nonprofit organizations exempt under IRC 501(c)(3) are liable when they pay $250 or more in a quarter or have four or more employees for some portion of a day in 20 weeks
Alaska does not levy a state personal income tax, so no withholding account is required.

agency_name: Arizona Department of Economic Security (DES) – Employer Registration Unit & Arizona Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: General employers become liable when they pay at least $1,500 in wages in a calendar quarter; domestic employers are liable when cash wages reach $1,000 in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers for part of a day in 20 weeks; nonprofits that are exempt under IRC 501(c)(3) become liable when they have four or more employees for part of a day in 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Liability also arises when at least one worker is employed for some part of a day in 20 weeks during a calendar year (for general employers); agricultural employers are liable when 10 or more workers are employed for part of a day in 20 weeks; nonprofits are liable when they employ four or more workers for part of a day in 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers who compensate employees for services performed in Arizona must deduct and remit state income tax beginning with the first payroll; all employers must register their EIN with the Arizona Department of Revenue by completing the Joint Tax Application (JT‑1).
typical_processing_time: 1–2 weeks (DES mails a determination letter after processing the application)
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
License types to register for (check Withholding/Unemployment Tax on the JT‑1/UC‑001 form)
Type of organization (sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, LLC, etc.)
Legal business name and any trade name (DBA)
Physical location and mailing address of the business
Business phone number, fax number and email address
Description of business and NAICS code
State of incorporation and date business started in Arizona
Date of first payroll in Arizona
Names, titles, Social Security numbers, addresses and contact information for all responsible owners, partners or corporate officers
filing_methods: Complete the Joint Tax Application (JT‑1/UC‑001) online at AZTaxes.gov to register for unemployment insurance and withholding
Alternatively, submit the paper JT‑1/UC‑001 form by mail to the Arizona Department of Revenue (processing is slower)
After registration, file quarterly wage reports and pay UI contributions through the DES Employer online services
confirmation_proof: DES mails a Determination of Unemployment Insurance Liability letter with the employer account number and tax rate after processing the Joint Tax Application; the Department of Revenue uses the employer’s FEIN as the withholding account number and issues a confirmation notice.
source_notes: Arizona DES explains that employers pay unemployment tax when they pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter or have one employee for 20 weeks; domestic employers are liable at $1,000; agricultural employers are liable at $20,000 or 10 workers for 20 weeks; nonprofits become liable when they employ four or more people for 20 weeks【152754052872605†L421-L437】.

The DES “Applying for an Unemployment Insurance Tax Account Number” instructions say new businesses must register with DES and the Department of Revenue by completing the Arizona Joint Tax Application (JT‑1/UC‑001); the application cannot be processed without a FEIN and DES mails a Determination of Liability letter with the employer account number and tax rate after processing【147277426253297†L405-L416】.

The Arizona Department of Revenue notes that every employer compensating an employee for services performed in Arizona must register its EIN via the Joint Tax Application and withhold state income tax from the first payroll【996119115762198†L129-L139】; once registered, the company’s EIN is its withholding ID and DES mails a determination letter if UI taxes are due【996119115762198†L142-L151】.
The DES contact page lists the Employer Registration Unit phone number (602‑771‑6602) and email uitstatus@azdes.gov【634438238097038†L470-L477】.

The Joint Tax Application (JT‑1/UC‑001) form shows that employers must provide their FEIN, organization type, business name and addresses, business phone/fax/email, description of business, NAICS code, state of incorporation, date business started, first payroll date, and names and Social Security numbers of owners/officers【807060179444228†L22-L69】.

notes: Arizona DES outlines liability thresholds for general, domestic, agricultural and nonprofit employers【152754052872605†L421-L437】.

The Arizona Department of Revenue states that employers must register and withhold state income tax for employees performing services in Arizona beginning with the first payroll【996119115762198†L129-L139】.

agency_name: Arkansas Division of Workforce Services
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employ one or more workers for 10 days or more during a calendar year; domestic employers become liable when cash wages total $1,000 or more in a quarter; agricultural employers become liable when cash wages total $20,000 in a quarter or when at least 10 workers are employed for some part of a day in 20 different weeks
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 10 days of employment for general liability; 20 different weeks with 10 workers for agricultural employment
withholding_threshold_description: Employers paying wages to employees in Arkansas must register with the Department of Finance and Administration for a withholding wage tax account and withhold Arkansas income tax beginning with the first payroll; registration is completed through the Arkansas Taxpayer Access Point (ATAP)
typical_processing_time: Employers registering online via the Tax21 or EZ Tax Registration system receive an employer account number upon approval; paper Form DWS‑ARK‑201 may take several weeks. Withholding registration via ATAP is processed online (time varies).
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal name and trade name of the business
Business physical and mailing addresses and phone number
Type of organization and date workers were first employed
Date and amount of first payroll and total quarterly wages
Names and Social Security numbers of owners/partners/officers
Information on acquisition or reorganization of another business
filing_methods: Online via Tax21/EZ Tax Registration (preferred) to file the ‘Report to Determine Liability Under the Division of Workforce Services Law’ (Form DWS‑ARK‑201)
Paper Form DWS‑ARK‑201 submitted to Employer Account Services
Withholding registration via Arkansas Taxpayer Access Point (ATAP)
confirmation_proof: Nine‑digit employer account number issued by the Division of Workforce Services; withholding registration yields an Arkansas withholding account number
source_notes: Arkansas Employer Handbook – employer liability criteria and account creation; Employer Account Services contact; ATAP contact information

agency_name: California Employment Development Department (EDD)
ui_wage_threshold_text: $100 in wages paid in a calendar quarter (general business); household employers are liable when cash wages reach $750 in a quarter; corporate officers who pay wages to themselves or family members are also subject to coverage
withholding_threshold_description: Employers paying wages to California residents or nonresidents for services performed in the state must register and withhold California state income tax beginning with the first payroll (few exceptions apply)
typical_processing_time: Employers who register online through e‑Services for Business receive their EDD account number immediately; paper registration by mail can take 10–14 days to process
required_information: Names and Social Security numbers of all responsible parties, owners, partners or corporate officers
Physical and mailing addresses, business telephone number and email address
Date of first payroll when wages exceeded $100 (or $750 for household employers)
Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Description of principal business activities (NAICS)
Previous EDD employer account number (if any) and previous owner’s information
Business name as registered with the California Secretary of State and associated ID numbers
DBA/trade names and contact person information
filing_methods: Online via EDD e‑Services for Business (preferred)
Paper forms (DE 1 for commercial employers, DE 1HW for household employers, DE 1NP for nonprofit employers, etc.)
confirmation_proof: Payroll tax account number (EDD employer account number) and confirmation letter issued by EDD
source_notes: EDD registration threshold and required information

notes: Corporate officers paying wages to themselves or family members are also subject
Exceptions may apply

agency_name: Colorado Department of Labor and Employment (CDLE) – Unemployment Insurance Division & Colorado Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: General employers become liable for unemployment insurance when they pay at least $1,500 in wages in a calendar quarter; domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in wages in a quarter; agricultural employers become liable when cash wages total $20,000 in a quarter; nonprofit 501(c)(3) employers become liable with four or more employees.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Liability also arises when one or more workers are employed for part of a day in 20 different weeks during a calendar year (general employers); agricultural employers become liable when ten or more agricultural workers are employed for part of a day in 20 weeks; nonprofit employers become liable when they have four or more workers for part of a day in 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers that pay wages to employees for services performed in Colorado must withhold Colorado income tax from the first payroll and must register for a wage withholding account with the Colorado Department of Revenue. Registration is available online through MyBizColorado or by filing the Wage Withholding Account Application (CR 0100).
typical_processing_time: Processing times vary; accounts are generally opened shortly after registration though certain account types may take 4–6 weeks to process【888360988188442†L146-L168】.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and any trade name (DBA)
Business entity type (corporation, sole proprietorship, partnership, LLC, nonprofit, etc.)
Principal business address and mailing address
Business phone number and email address
Date business began in Colorado and first date of payroll
Location of payroll records
Names, Social Security numbers and titles of all owners, partners and corporate officers
Description of business activities and NAICS code
Banking information for electronic payments (optional)
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance and withholding tax online through MyBizColorado (mybiz.colorado.gov)
Alternatively, complete the UITL‑100 Application for Unemployment Insurance Account and Determination of Employer Liability and mail it to the CDLE
For withholding only, out‑of‑state businesses may complete Form CR 0100 (Wage Withholding Account Application) and mail or fax it to the Department of Revenue
confirmation_proof: After registration, CDLE issues a letter with the employer account number and tax rate; the Department of Revenue assigns a wage withholding account number (usually your FEIN) and sends a confirmation letter.
source_notes: The Colorado Department of Labor and Employment explains that employers are liable for UI when they pay at least $1,500 in wages in a quarter or employ one or more workers for part of a day in 20 weeks; domestic employers are liable when paying $1,000; agricultural employers at $20,000 or 10 workers for 20 weeks; nonprofits become liable when they have four or more employees for 20 weeks【717600325440359†L322-L396】.

The Colorado Department of Revenue’s withholding accounts page notes that employers who must withhold Colorado income tax must apply for a withholding tax account and that there is no fee; businesses inside Colorado can register via MyBizColorado or the Wage Withholding Account Application (CR 0100); accounts for certain purposes may take 4–6 weeks to process【888360988188442†L146-L168】.

UI Employer Services contact numbers (303‑318‑9100 and 1‑800‑480‑8299) are provided on the employer liability chart page【717600325440359†L458-L468】, and the Department of Revenue tax helpline (303‑238‑7378) is listed on the Contact Us page【227704874308306†L130-L142】.
The UITL‑100 form requires FEIN, business entity type, business name and address, first payroll date, names and Social Security numbers of owners/officers, and other details【600275258200365†L25-L80】.

notes: Liability thresholds for general, domestic, agricultural and nonprofit employers are described by CDLE【717600325440359†L322-L396】.
Employers paying wages for services performed in Colorado must register for a wage withholding account and withhold state income tax from the first payroll【888360988188442†L146-L168】.

agency_name: Connecticut Department of Labor – Employer Status Unit & Connecticut Department of Revenue Services (DRS)
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers become liable for unemployment contributions when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter; domestic employers become liable when cash wages total $1,000 in a quarter; agricultural employers become liable when cash wages total $20,000 in a quarter; nonprofit 501(c)(3) organizations become liable if they have at least one employee.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Liability also arises when one or more employees work for some portion of a day in each of twenty different weeks during the current or preceding year (general employers); agricultural employers become liable when ten or more workers are employed for part of a day in 20 weeks; nonprofit employers become liable when they have one or more employees for some portion of a day in 13 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers that maintain an office or transact business in Connecticut must register for Connecticut income tax withholding through myconneCT and begin withholding tax from the first payroll, even if they are already registered for other taxes.
typical_processing_time: 1–2 weeks (registration through myconneCT is immediate; official permit letter may arrive later)
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN) or Social Security number
Legal business name and any “doing business as” (DBA) name
Physical and mailing address of the business
Business phone number, fax number and email address
Type of organization (corporation, LLC, sole proprietorship, partnership, etc.) and NAICS code
Names and Social Security numbers of responsible owners, partners or corporate officers
Banking information for payment of permit fees or taxes
Date the business started in Connecticut and first date wages were paid
Description of business activities
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance online at the Connecticut Department of Labor’s Employer Status portal (ct.gov/doltax)
Register for Connecticut income tax withholding through myconneCT (portal.ct.gov/DRS)
Employers may also contact the Employer Status Unit to obtain paper forms if necessary, but online registration is required
confirmation_proof: After registration, the Connecticut Department of Labor assigns an unemployment insurance employer account number and tax rate; the Department of Revenue Services issues a permit number and confirmation via myconneCT.
source_notes: The Connecticut Employer’s Guide states that employers must register for unemployment insurance online and become liable when they pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter or have one or more employees for some portion of a day in each of 20 weeks【959957717358738†L190-L207】【959957717358738†L259-L266】. Domestic employers are liable at $1,000 in cash wages, agricultural employers at $20,000 in cash wages or when 10 workers are employed for 20 weeks, and nonprofit 501(c)(3) organizations are liable when they have an employee for part of a day in thirteen weeks【959957717358738†L303-L345】.

The Connecticut Department of Revenue Services notes that employers starting a new business must register for Connecticut income tax withholding through myconneCT and that employers with an office or transacting business in Connecticut must withhold from employees’ wages【826850261466679†L85-L115】.

The DRS new‑business registration flyer lists information needed to register such as FEIN/SSN, legal name, DBA, business address, banking information and names and Social Security numbers of responsible owners or officers【741432796974868†L40-L57】.
The same flyer provides helpline phone numbers for DRS new business registration assistance【741432796974868†L166-L205】.

notes: Liability thresholds and special rules for general, domestic, agricultural and nonprofit employers are explained in the Connecticut Employer’s Guide【959957717358738†L259-L345】.
Connecticut DRS requires employers to register through myconneCT and withhold income tax from employees’ wages from the first payroll【826850261466679†L85-L115】.

agency_name: Delaware Department of Labor – Division of Unemployment Insurance & Delaware Division of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: General employers are liable when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter; domestic employers become liable when cash wages total $1,000 in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter; government and nonprofit employers are covered even though they are not liable under FUTA.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Liability also arises when at least one employee works for some portion of a day on 20 different days in a year (general employers); agricultural employers become liable when they have 10 or more workers on 20 different days; nonprofits and governmental employers are liable when they have one or more employees in 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Every employer who maintains an office or transacts business in Delaware and pays wages subject to withholding must register by completing the Combined Registration Application (CRA); employers use their federal EIN as the withholding identification number. Out‑of‑state employers who pay wages to Delaware residents must register as withholding agents via Delaware One Stop.
typical_processing_time: Employer account numbers are issued after the Division of Unemployment Insurance processes Form UC‑1; processing time varies but typically takes a few weeks.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name (if any)
Physical location and mailing address of the business
Business phone number and email address
Type of organization and description of business activities
Date the business started and date of first payroll in Delaware
Employment history for the last five years including acquisitions and predecessor businesses
Names, titles and Social Security numbers of owners, partners or corporate officers
filing_methods: Complete Form UC‑1 (Report to Determine Liability and Application for Employer Account Number) and return it within 20 days of the first day of business to the Delaware Division of Unemployment Insurance
Employers may download the UC‑1 from the Department of Labor website or request it by phone; some information can be submitted through Delaware One Stop
For withholding, complete the Combined Registration Application (CRA) online through the Division of Revenue or register as a withholding agent via Delaware One Stop
confirmation_proof: The Division of Unemployment Insurance reviews Form UC‑1 and assigns an employer account number along with a Notice of Coverage poster; the Division of Revenue uses the employer’s FEIN as the withholding ID and issues a permit letter.
source_notes: The Delaware Division of Finance and Department of Labor explain that employers are liable for unemployment taxes when they pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter or employ at least one person for 20 days; agricultural employers are liable at $20,000 in wages or 10 workers for 20 days; domestic employers are liable when cash wages total $1,000【608774991962551†L10-L28】.

The Department of Labor’s Employer FAQs note that employers must file Form UC‑1 within 20 days of the first day of business; the form determines liability and establishes an employer account number and must be returned promptly【290452695497594†L119-L181】.

The Delaware UI Employer Handbook restates the liability thresholds and states that employers receive an account number and Notice of Coverage when liability is established; contact numbers are provided for questions【452469301903578†L592-L652】【452469301903578†L657-L693】.

The handbook explains that Form UC‑1 requests information about the nature of the business, organization type, changes in status, employment history and acquisitions, and must be returned within ten days【452469301903578†L1571-L1581】【452469301903578†L1588-L1590】.

The Delaware Division of Revenue’s Employer Guide states that employers who maintain an office or transact business in Delaware and pay wages subject to withholding must register using the Combined Registration Application; the FEIN becomes the withholding ID number【121947700220292†L54-L67】 and contact information for the withholding department is provided【121947700220292†L123-L137】. The One Stop site also notes that out‑of‑state employers may register as withholding agents when paying Delaware wages【525710931876080†L38-L59】.

notes: Delaware liability rules require general employers to pay at least $1,500 in wages or have an employee on 20 days; domestic employers are liable at $1,000; agricultural employers at $20,000 or 10 workers for 20 days; government and nonprofit employers are covered and may elect reimbursement【608774991962551†L10-L28】.

The Delaware Division of Revenue requires employers who maintain an office or do business in Delaware and pay wages subject to withholding to register using the Combined Registration Application and withhold from the first payroll【121947700220292†L54-L67】.

agency_name: Florida Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in wages in a calendar quarter or one or more employees for 20 weeks; agricultural employers become liable at $10,000 cash wages in a quarter or five workers for 20 weeks; domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in wages in a quarter
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 weeks with at least one employee (general employment)
withholding_threshold_description: Florida has no individual income tax; employers therefore do not need to register for state wage withholding
typical_processing_time: The online Florida Business Tax Application processes registrations in about three business days; paper Form DR‑1 processing may take longer
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN) or Social Security number
Reason for applying (opening a new business, adding a location, etc.)
Legal name and trade name of the business
Physical and mailing addresses and telephone number
Form of business ownership (corporation, partnership, sole proprietor, etc.)
Date of first taxable transaction/first wages paid
Names, addresses and Social Security numbers of business owners/officers
filing_methods: Online Florida Business Tax Application (interactive wizard)
Paper Form DR‑1 mailed to the Department of Revenue
confirmation_proof: Reemployment Tax Account Number and Certificate of Registration mailed after processing
source_notes: Florida DOR reemployment tax liability and processing time

notes: Florida has no individual income tax

agency_name: Georgia Department of Labor
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in gross payroll in a calendar quarter or one worker in 20 different weeks in a year; agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 in a quarter or have 10 or more workers for 20 weeks; domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one worker (general employment)
withholding_threshold_description: Employers with employees performing services in Georgia must register and withhold Georgia income tax from the first wages paid to resident and nonresident employees; registration is through the Georgia Tax Center (gtc.dor.ga.gov)
typical_processing_time: Online registration through the Employer Portal yields an account number immediately; paper Employer Status Report (Form DOL‑1N) may take up to 30 days for processing
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Date of first Georgia hire and date of first Georgia payroll
Date of incorporation or business formation
Names, addresses and Social Security numbers of all owners, partners or corporate officers
Current mailing address
Type of business (corporation, LLC, sole proprietorship, etc.)
Description of business activities and NAICS code
Information about any acquisition of an existing business (name of prior owner, account number and date of purchase)
filing_methods: Online via GDOL Employer Portal (preferred)
Paper Employer Status Report (Form DOL‑1N) submitted by mail
confirmation_proof: Employer account number and determination letter issued by the Georgia Department of Labor
source_notes: GDOL liability thresholds and registration processing time

agency_name: Hawaii Department of Labor and Industrial Relations – Unemployment Insurance Division & Hawaii Department of Taxation
ui_wage_threshold_text: Hawaii covers most employers who hire one or more individuals to perform services in the state. Agricultural labor is excluded from coverage if the employer pays less than $20,000 in cash wages in each quarter and employs nine or fewer agricultural workers or has fewer than 20 weeks of agricultural work; domestic service is excluded if cash remuneration is less than $1,000 in a quarter. Casual labor, family employment and small fishing vessel crews are also excluded.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Liability generally arises when an employer hires at least one individual to perform services in Hawaii; agricultural employers become liable when they have 10 or more workers in 20 weeks or pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in each quarter; domestic employers become liable when cash wages total $1,000 in a quarter.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers paying wages for services performed in Hawaii (or wages paid from a Hawaii office) must withhold Hawaii income tax from the first payroll. Employers must obtain a Hawaii Tax Identification Number for withholding by submitting Form BB‑1 or registering through Hawaii Tax Online.
typical_processing_time: 1–2 weeks (no fee to open a withholding account, and account numbers are usually issued shortly after registration)
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name (if any)
Physical location of the business in Hawaii and mailing address
Business phone number, fax number and email address
Type of business organization and date business started in Hawaii
Date employees were first hired in Hawaii and date of first payroll
Names, titles and Social Security numbers of owners, partners or corporate officers
Nature of the business and NAICS code
filing_methods: Register for a Hawaii unemployment insurance account online at uiclaims.hawaii.gov; paper Form UC‑1 is no longer accepted
For withholding, complete Form BB‑1 (Basic Business Application) or register online through Hawaii Tax Online to obtain a Hawaii Tax ID number
Quarterly UI wage and tax reports must be filed electronically even if no wages are paid
confirmation_proof: After submitting the online application, the Hawaii Department of Labor determines liability and issues a UI account number and Notice to Employees; the Department of Taxation issues a Hawaii Tax ID number and confirmation letter for withholding registration.
source_notes: Hawaii’s Unemployment Insurance Handbook explains that paper Form UC‑1 is no longer accepted and employers must register online; employers must file a status report within 20 days after hiring an employee to obtain a UI account number【715477831091302†L84-L99】.

The coverage exclusions page states that employers with one or more individuals are generally subject to coverage; agricultural labor is excluded if wages are less than $20,000 per quarter and there are nine or fewer employees or less than 20 weeks of agricultural work; domestic service is excluded if remuneration is less than $1,000 per quarter【549767931418783†L48-L67】.
The UI forms page notes that employers must register online at uiclaims.hawaii.gov and lists phone numbers for registration assistance on Oahu, Hawaii Island, Maui and Kauai【683219072822275†L52-L61】.

The Hawaii Department of Taxation states that employers must withhold Hawaii income tax on wages for services performed in the state, and that employers can request a withholding account number by completing Form BB‑1 or registering through Hawaii Tax Online; no fee is charged to open the account【113556195976741†L75-L128】.

Booklet A: Employer’s Tax Guide explains that new employers must obtain a Hawaii Tax ID number using Form BB‑1, obtain a federal EIN, and register with the Unemployment Insurance Division within 20 days after services are first performed【124553436147000†L380-L403】.

notes: Hawaii covers most employers from the first worker, but agricultural labor is excluded until $20,000 in cash wages or 10 workers in 20 weeks, and domestic service is excluded until $1,000 in wages【549767931418783†L48-L67】.

The Hawaii Department of Taxation requires employers to withhold income tax on wages performed in Hawaii from the first payroll and to obtain a Hawaii Tax ID number via Form BB‑1 or online registration【113556195976741†L75-L128】.

agency_name: Idaho Department of Labor – Unemployment Insurance Division & Idaho State Tax Commission
ui_wage_threshold_text: General employers become liable for unemployment insurance when they pay $1,500 or more in total wages in any calendar quarter; domestic employers are liable when cash wages total $1,000 in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter; nonprofit and governmental employers are subject from the first dollar of wages.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Liability also arises when one or more individuals work for some portion of a week in 20 different weeks during a calendar year (general employers); agricultural employers become liable when ten or more individuals work for some portion of a week in 20 different weeks; nonprofit and governmental employers are covered from the first day wages are paid.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers with employees earning income while in Idaho must register for an Idaho withholding account and withhold income tax from the first payroll; this applies to all employees including agricultural, household and family members, and to residents working outside Idaho if tax is voluntarily withheld. Employers who fail to register may be subject to civil penalties.
typical_processing_time: The Idaho State Tax Commission sends the withholding account number and filing cycle within about 10 business days after receiving the application【833475292205908†L430-L458】.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN) and Social Security number (for sole proprietors)
Legal business name and assumed business name (DBA)
Date incorporated and state of incorporation
Date business began in Idaho and physical location of Idaho operations
Mailing address and business telephone number
Contact person name, title, phone number and email address
Type of business, primary activities and NAICS code
Estimated monthly taxable sales and whether the business will sell tangible personal property
Names, addresses and Social Security numbers of owners, partners or corporate officers
Date employees were first hired and date of first paycheck
filing_methods: Complete the Idaho Business Registration (IBR‑1) online at business.idaho.gov (fastest) to register for unemployment insurance and withholding
Alternatively, submit the paper IBR‑1 form by mail or fax to the Idaho Department of Labor and Idaho State Tax Commission
File quarterly UI wage and tax reports through the Employer Portal at labor.idaho.gov/employerportal
confirmation_proof: After submitting the Idaho Business Registration form, the Department of Labor determines coverage and issues a UI account number; the Idaho State Tax Commission issues a withholding account number and filing instructions within 10 business days.
source_notes: The Idaho Unemployment Insurance Tax Information handbook states that employers must report wages and pay UI tax if, during the current or preceding year, total wages of $1,500 or more were paid in a quarter or one or more individuals worked for some portion of a week in 20 different weeks; agricultural employers are liable at $20,000 in cash wages or 10 workers for 20 weeks; domestic employers at $1,000 in cash wages; governmental and nonprofit 501(c)(3) employers are covered from the first dollar【42846448966547†L274-L279】【42846448966547†L290-L296】【42846448966547†L348-L351】【42846448966547†L426-L437】.
The handbook notes that all new businesses must submit the Idaho Business Registration form online at business.idaho.gov within six months of becoming a covered employer【42846448966547†L29-L40】.

The IBR‑1 form requires information such as FEIN, Social Security numbers of owners, legal business name, DBA, incorporation details, business addresses and contact information, type of business, estimated taxable sales, and dates employees were hired and first paid【824837863105032†L54-L96】【824837863105032†L165-L169】【824837863105032†L202-L203】.

The Guide to Idaho Income Tax Withholding states that employers must register for a withholding account if they have employees earning income in Idaho and must withhold from the first payroll; failure to register may result in civil penalties【833475292205908†L290-L301】.

The same guide explains that the Tax Commission sends a withholding account number and filing cycle within 10 business days after receiving the application and that the easiest way to apply is through the online business permit application【833475292205908†L430-L458】.
Contact information for the Idaho Department of Labor and the Idaho State Tax Commission is provided in the guide【833475292205908†L35-L37】.

notes: Idaho UI liability thresholds for general, domestic, agricultural, and nonprofit/government employers are given in the Unemployment Insurance Tax Information handbook【42846448966547†L274-L279】【42846448966547†L290-L296】【42846448966547†L426-L437】.

Employers with employees earning income in Idaho must register for an Idaho withholding account and withhold income tax from the first payroll; the Tax Commission sends account numbers within about 10 business days【833475292205908†L290-L301】【833475292205908†L430-L458】.

agency_name: Illinois Department of Employment Security (IDES)
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in wages in a calendar quarter or one worker employed in 20 different weeks during a calendar year; domestic employers become liable at $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 in cash wages in a quarter or have 10 or more workers for 20 weeks; nonprofit organizations are liable when they employ four or more persons in each of 20 weeks in a year
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 weeks with at least one employee (general employment); 20 weeks with 4 or more employees (nonprofit organizations)
withholding_threshold_description: Employers that are required to withhold federal income tax from compensation paid for services performed in Illinois must register and withhold Illinois income tax from the first payroll; registration and filing are completed through MyTax Illinois
typical_processing_time: Registration through MyTax Illinois is generally processed within one to two business days; paper Form REG‑UI‑1 filings may take four to six weeks
required_information: Business legal name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses, telephone number and email address
Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Previously assigned employer account number (if any)
Type of organization (corporation, partnership, sole proprietor, etc.)
Primary business activity and NAICS code
Date the business was formed or incorporated
Date the business first employed workers in Illinois and date of first payroll
Information about acquisitions or transfers of another business
Details about domestic service and agricultural employment if applicable
filing_methods: Online registration via MyTax Illinois (preferred)
Paper Report to Determine Liability Under the Unemployment Insurance Act (Form REG‑UI‑1)
confirmation_proof: IDES employer account number and tax rate notice (sent after registration)
source_notes: Illinois liability thresholds and registration details

agency_name: Indiana Department of Workforce Development
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1 in wages paid to a covered worker (non‑agricultural employment); agricultural employers become liable when cash wages total $20,000 in a calendar quarter or when 10 or more agricultural workers are employed for 20 weeks in a calendar year
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 weeks for agriculture if 10 or more workers are employed
withholding_threshold_description: Employers paying wages to residents or nonresidents for work performed in Indiana must register and withhold state income tax from the first payroll (non‑resident employees from reciprocal states may be exempt; nonresident employees from other states have a 30‑day safe harbor)
typical_processing_time: Most online registrations receive an employer account number within several business days; paper Form 2837 filings take longer
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal name and trade name of the business
Business physical and mailing address and telephone number
Entity type (corporation, LLC, sole proprietor, etc.)
Date of first wages paid and total gross wages for the prior quarter
Number of employees and type of employment (regular, agricultural, nonprofit)
Names, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners/officers
filing_methods: Online via Uplink Employer Self‑Service (preferred)
Paper Form 2837 (SUTA Account Number Application) mailed to the Department
confirmation_proof: Employer Account Number and confirmation letter issued by the Department of Workforce Development
source_notes: Indiana Employer Handbook – liability threshold and registration instructions

notes: non-agricultural coverage starts at $1 in wages
Reciprocal state exemptions and 30-day safe harbor for nonresident employees

agency_name: Iowa Workforce Development – Unemployment Insurance Tax Bureau & Iowa Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers become liable for unemployment insurance when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter; domestic employers are liable when cash wages total $1,000 in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when cash wages total $20,000 in a quarter; nonprofit 501(c)(3) employers are liable when their payroll is $1,500 or more.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Liability also arises when one or more employees perform covered services in at least 20 different weeks in a calendar year (general employers); agricultural employers become liable when they have 10 or more workers for some portion of a day in 20 weeks; nonprofit employers are liable when they have one or more employees for 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers with employees working in Iowa must register for an Iowa withholding tax permit and withhold Iowa income tax from the first payroll; registration is done through GovConnectIowa. Out‑of‑state employers must register if they withhold Iowa income tax from wages.
typical_processing_time: Account numbers may be available as soon as one business day when registering online through GovConnectIowa, but permit letters may take up to six weeks to arrive by mail【9342701929592†L100-L104】.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical location and mailing address of the business
Business phone number and email address
Type of organization and NAICS code
Names, addresses and Social Security numbers of owners, partners or corporate officers
Date the business began and first date wages were paid in Iowa
Number of employees and estimated payroll
Contact person name, phone number and email
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance online through myIowaUI (myiowaui.org) within 30 days after first paying wages
Register for an Iowa withholding tax permit online through GovConnectIowa
Employers can also mail the Business Tax Registration form (IDR 78‑005) for withholding, but online registration is faster
confirmation_proof: MyIowaUI provides an unemployment insurance account number upon successful registration; IWD sends an official determination letter by mail; the Iowa Department of Revenue issues a withholding permit and account number via GovConnectIowa and mails a permit letter.
source_notes: The Iowa Report to Determine Liability for Unemployment Insurance Tax states that employers become liable when they have one or more employees performing covered services in 20 different weeks or when payroll reaches $1,500 in a calendar quarter; agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 in wages or have 10 workers for 20 weeks; domestic employers at $1,000 in wages; nonprofits at $1,500 or one employee for 20 weeks【476717311618928†L10-L49】.

Iowa Workforce Development instructs employers to register their UI tax account within 30 days after the first date wages are paid through the myIowaUI online system【724798525969700†L129-L134】; the Employer Systems page provides contact details for the UI Tax Bureau【355852252465050†L175-L182】.

GovConnectIowa explains that new tax permit registration requires information such as legal name, location and mailing address, FEIN, NAICS code, names and Social Security numbers of managing owners/officers and contact details【569019166298780†L236-L246】.

Information from the Iowa Department of Revenue notes that after completing registration, employers may receive their account number as soon as one business day, but the permit letter may take up to six weeks by mail【9342701929592†L100-L104】.

notes: Iowa UI liability thresholds for general, domestic, agricultural and nonprofit employers are provided in the Report to Determine Liability for Unemployment Insurance Tax【476717311618928†L10-L49】.

Employers with employees working in Iowa must register for an Iowa withholding tax permit and withhold Iowa income tax from the first payroll; registration may be completed through GovConnectIowa【9342701929592†L100-L104】.

agency_name: Kansas Department of Labor Employer Services and Kansas Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in wages in any calendar quarter for general employers; household employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers become liable when cash wages reach $20,000 in a quarter; nonprofit employers become liable when they have four or more workers.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with one or more workers for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employment; 20 weeks with four or more workers for 501(c)(3) nonprofits; household employment has no weeks test.
withholding_threshold_description: Any employer paying wages subject to federal withholding must register for a Kansas withholding tax account and withhold Kansas income tax from employees. Registration is required before the first payroll.
typical_processing_time: Employers receive their Kansas Employer Serial Number within two days of submitting the online Status Report and the unemployment account number is assigned immediately; the Kansas Department of Revenue issues the withholding tax account number upon completion of the online Business Tax Application.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses, phone number and email of the business
Type of ownership and date and state of organization
Date employment began in Kansas and date first wages were paid
Total wages paid in the quarter and number of employees
Names, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, or corporate officers
Business activity or NAICS code
Whether the business acquired or merged with another employer
For nonprofit entities, a copy of the 501(c)(3) exemption
filing_methods: Online via the Kansas Employer Self Service portal to file the Status Report (Form K‑CNS 010) and obtain a Kansas unemployment account number
Mail Form K‑CNS 010 (Employer Status Report) to the Kansas Department of Labor
Online via the Kansas Department of Revenue Business Tax Application (Form CR‑16) to register for withholding and other taxes
Mail Form CR‑16 to the Kansas Department of Revenue
confirmation_proof: A Kansas unemployment account number and employer rate notice issued by the Department of Labor; a Kansas withholding tax account number issued by the Department of Revenue.
source_notes: Employer Handbook and Kansas Department of Labor Status Report requirements for liability and registration; GoCo payroll tax registration article for withholding and required information; Kansas Department of Labor Employer Services and Kansas Department of Revenue sites for registration portals and contact details; articles on employer serial number issuance and processing time.

agency_name: Kentucky Office of Unemployment Insurance and Kentucky Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in wages in a calendar quarter for general employers; $1,000 in wages in a quarter for household employers; $20,000 in wages in a quarter for agricultural employers; nonprofits become liable when they have four or more workers.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employment; 20 weeks with four or more employees for nonprofit organizations; no weeks test for household employment.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must withhold Kentucky income tax from wages paid to employees working in Kentucky when they are required to withhold federal income tax; registration for a Kentucky withholding tax account is required before paying wages.
typical_processing_time: The Kentucky Employer Identification Number (KEIN) for unemployment insurance is issued immediately upon completion of the online registration. The withholding tax account number is mailed or emailed after the Department of Revenue processes the registration.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and any trade name
Physical and mailing addresses, telephone and email
Entity type (sole proprietor, partnership, corporation, LLC) and date formed
Date employment began in Kentucky and date first payroll was paid
Total wages paid in the quarter and number of employees
Names, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners or corporate officers
Description of business activity or NAICS code
Whether the business acquired another company or changed its organization
For nonprofits, evidence of 501(c)(3) status
filing_methods: Online via the Kentucky Unemployment Insurance Self Service portal to file the Employer Application and obtain a KEIN
Mail employer application documents to the Kentucky Office of Unemployment Insurance
Online via the Kentucky Business One Stop Portal to complete the Kentucky Tax Registration Application (Form 10A100) for withholding
Mail Form 10A100 to the Kentucky Department of Revenue
confirmation_proof: A Kentucky Employer Identification Number (KEIN) and contribution rate notice from the Office of Unemployment Insurance; a Kentucky withholding tax account number issued by the Department of Revenue.
source_notes: Kentucky Unemployment Insurance Employer Guide for liability thresholds; Kentucky Career Center and Business One Stop portal for registration; GoCo payroll tax article for required information and processing times; Kentucky UI Tax enforcement contact page and Department of Revenue contact page for contact information.

agency_name: Louisiana Workforce Commission (unemployment) and Louisiana Department of Revenue
registration_portal_url: https://laors9.laworks.net/LaStarsRegistration (UI account application); https://revenue.louisiana.gov (LDR Online Business Registration)
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers generally become liable when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in any quarter or employ at least one worker for part of a day in 20 or more separate weeks in a year; domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when they have 10 or more workers for 20 weeks or pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter; nonprofit organizations (501(c)(3)) become liable when they employ four or more individuals for 20 weeks
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 separate weeks with at least one worker (general); 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more workers for nonprofit employers
withholding_threshold_description: Employers paying wages to workers in Louisiana must register with the Louisiana Department of Revenue to obtain a Revenue Account Number and withhold state income tax from those wages; registration is completed through the online Business Registration portal or by submitting Form R-16019 before paying wages
typical_processing_time: Unemployment account numbers are generally issued three to five business days after an online application; withholding registrations completed online issue a Revenue Account Number within days after submission
required_information: Employer's name
Louisiana physical address (or job site/employee address)
Mailing addresses and phone numbers
Payroll contact person name and telephone number
Organization type (e.g., corporation, sole proprietorship, LLC)
Date and state where the business entity was formed
Employer type (Regular, Agricultural, Non‑Profit or Government)
Number of employees working in Louisiana
Federal Identification Number (FEIN)
Louisiana withholding number (if already obtained)
Information on Professional Employer Organization (PEO), acquisitions or changes in FEIN
Date the company first had employees in Louisiana and quarter the qualification was met
Officer/owner information (names, titles, Social Security numbers, addresses)
Type of business activities and contact person for additional information
List of employees and Social Security numbers if part of an acquisition
Copy of 501(c)(3) exemption for nonprofit entities
filing_methods: Online via the Louisiana Workforce Commission Employer Application portal (laors9.laworks.net) for unemployment insurance
Online via the Louisiana Department of Revenue Business Registration portal (LDR Online Business Registration or LaTAP) for withholding tax
Paper Form R‑16019 mailed to the Louisiana Department of Revenue for withholding registration
confirmation_proof: Louisiana Workforce Commission issues an Employer Account Number and contribution rate after application; the Department of Revenue sends a Revenue Account Number for withholding registration

contacts.phone: 1‑833‑708‑2866 (UI tax) or 1‑866‑783‑5567 for employer registration; withholding tax questions: 855‑307‑3893

source_notes: Louisiana Unemployment Insurance Tax Guide for Employers (2025) details liability thresholds, domestic, agricultural, and nonprofit thresholds and registration requirements; LWC Employer Application portal lists required information for the unemployment account application; Louisiana Department of Revenue FAQ explains that employers must apply for a Revenue Account Number via the online registration application or Form R‑16019 before withholding tax.

agency_name: Maine Department of Labor, Bureau of Unemployment Compensation and Maine Revenue Services
registration_portal_url: https://assist.reemployme.maine.gov/ep/landing (ReEmployME employer portal); https://revenue.maine.gov (Maine Tax Portal for withholding)
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers generally become liable when they pay $1,500 or more in gross wages in a calendar quarter or employ at least one individual for part of a day in 20 weeks in a year; agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages during a quarter or employ at least 10 workers in agricultural labor for 20 weeks; nonprofit organizations (501(c)(3)) become liable when they employ four or more individuals for 20 weeks; domestic employers are liable once they pay $1,000 or more in wages in a quarter
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 weeks with at least one employee (general); 20 weeks with 10 or more agricultural workers; 20 weeks with four or more employees for nonprofit employers
withholding_threshold_description: Employers who pay wages to employees working in Maine must register with Maine Revenue Services for a withholding tax account before remitting state income tax; registration is completed through the Maine Tax Portal by selecting “Register a New Business,” and there is no minimum payroll threshold.
typical_processing_time: Unemployment Employer Account Numbers and contribution rates are typically issued within 5–7 business days when registering through the ReEmployME portal; Maine Revenue Services mails the withholding account number approximately 20 days after online registration
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Business physical and mailing addresses and phone numbers
Primary contact person’s name and phone number
Type of organization (corporation, partnership, sole proprietor, LLC)
Date payroll operations began and date business entity was formed
Number of employees and first payroll date in Maine
Names, addresses, and Social Security numbers of owners or corporate officers
Description of business activities and NAICS code
Information on any predecessor or acquired business
Whether the business uses a professional employer organization (PEO) or third‑party administrator
filing_methods: Online via the ReEmployME Employer Portal for unemployment tax registration and quarterly wage reporting
Online via the Maine Tax Portal to register for an income tax withholding account and file quarterly returns
Paper withholding forms (such as Form 941ME) may be mailed if electronic filing is unavailable
confirmation_proof: The Maine Department of Labor sends an Employer Account Number (EAN) and contribution rate for unemployment insurance; Maine Revenue Services sends a Withholding Account Number letter after registration
source_notes: Maine Employer’s Guide to the Employment Security Law (2021) provides the $1,500/20‑week general threshold and lists agricultural, domestic, and nonprofit liability conditions; the guide also gives contact information for employer services; the ReEmployME portal page indicates that employers register a new business; the Justworks article describes registering through the Maine Tax Portal and states that unemployment account numbers are issued within 5–7 business days and withholding account numbers are mailed about 20 days after registration.

agency_name: Maryland Department of Labor – Division of Unemployment Insurance and Comptroller of Maryland
registration_portal_url: https://employer.beacon.labor.md.gov (BEACON unemployment insurance portal); https://interactive.marylandtaxes.gov/Business/Registration (Combined Registration Application); https://taxconnect.marylandtaxes.gov (Maryland Tax Connect)
ui_wage_threshold_text: General employers are subject to Maryland’s unemployment insurance law as soon as they employ at least one worker in the state; there is no minimum wage threshold. Agricultural labor is exempt from coverage unless cash wages reach $20,000 in a quarter or 10 or more individuals are employed during the current or preceding quarter, and domestic service is exempt unless the employer pays at least $1,000 in cash wages during a quarter
ui_threshold_weeks_text: No weeks test applies for general employers because liability begins with the first employee. Agricultural employers become liable when they employ 10 or more workers on any day in 20 weeks in a calendar year. Domestic employers do not have a weeks test; their liability is triggered only by wages. Non‑profit employers are treated like general employers and are liable when they have at least one employee.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register for a Maryland withholding tax account before paying wages and withhold state income tax whenever wages are subject to federal income tax. Registration is completed through the Maryland Tax Connect portal or the Combined Registration application.
typical_processing_time: The Maryland unemployment insurance employer account number (SUTA number) is generally issued within four to six weeks after registration, while state withholding tax account registration through Maryland Tax Connect or the Combined Registration application typically takes about two weeks to process.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and any trade names
Physical work site and mailing addresses in Maryland, business phone number and email
Business entity type (sole proprietor, corporation, partnership, LLC) and state/date of formation
Date wages were first paid in Maryland and date employment began
Names, titles, and Social Security numbers of all owners, partners or corporate officers
Description of the principal business activity and North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code
Maryland withholding or sales tax number (if already assigned)
Quarter and year the business met liability for unemployment insurance (if applicable)
For non‑profit entities, a copy of the IRS 501(c)(3) determination letter
Information about any predecessor or acquired businesses and lists of employees if part of an acquisition
filing_methods: Online via the BEACON employer portal to register for a Maryland unemployment insurance account
Online through the Combined Registration application to apply for withholding and unemployment insurance accounts simultaneously
Online via Maryland Tax Connect to register solely for a state withholding tax account
Submit paper Combined Registration forms (e.g., Combined Registration Application) by mail if not filing online
confirmation_proof: Employers receive a Maryland unemployment insurance employer account number and rate notice from the Division of Unemployment Insurance and a Maryland withholding tax account number from the Comptroller’s office after registration is processed.

contacts.phone: 410-949-0033 (Employer Call Center for UI registration questions); 410-767-2414 (Division of Unemployment Insurance general line); 410-260-7980 or 1-800-638-2937 (Comptroller of Maryland withholding tax help)

source_notes: The unemployment insurance liability thresholds and exemptions come from the Maryland Department of Labor’s Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages scope of coverage section, which states that employers are subject to Maryland’s UI law as soon as they employ at least one worker and lists agricultural and domestic exemptions. The required information for BEACON and the Combined Registration application is compiled from the Division of Unemployment Insurance instructions page, which directs employers to provide business and owner details, dates of formation and first wages, NAICS codes, predecessor information and 501(c)(3) status. Processing times are drawn from the Patriot Software SUTA guide (four–six weeks for the SUTA number) and the GoCo article noting that Combined Registration and Tax Connect submissions take about two weeks.

agency_name: Massachusetts Department of Unemployment Assistance and Massachusetts Department of Revenue
registration_portal_url: https://unemployment.mass.gov (Unemployment Services for Employers portal); https://mtc.dor.state.ma.us (MassTaxConnect)
ui_wage_threshold_text: For-profit employers must pay unemployment insurance contributions if they have employees working at least one day in any 13 weeks during a calendar year or pay wages of $1,500 or more in any calendar quarter【436281299933108†L176-L179】. Agricultural employers become liable when they pay $40,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more individuals on any day in 20 weeks of a calendar year【436281299933108†L180-L182】. Employers of domestic workers become liable once $1,000 or more is paid in cash wages in a calendar quarter【365994320666717†L260-L280】.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: General employers become liable if they employ at least one worker for one or more days in 13 weeks in a calendar year【436281299933108†L176-L179】. Agricultural employers become liable when they employ 10 or more workers on any day in 20 weeks in a calendar year【436281299933108†L180-L182】. Domestic employers do not have a weeks test; liability is triggered once wages paid reach $1,000【365994320666717†L260-L280】. Non‑profit employers are treated like general employers and are liable with one or more employees.
withholding_threshold_description: Massachusetts employers must register for a state withholding account and withhold state income tax from employees whenever wages are subject to federal tax. Registration should occur before the first payroll and is completed through the MassTaxConnect portal.
typical_processing_time: Massachusetts issues both the employer unemployment account number and the state withholding account number immediately upon completion of the online registration through the Unemployment Services for Employers portal and MassTaxConnect【963352479712058†L109-L119】.
required_information: Legal business name and Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal entity type and state and date of incorporation
Social Security numbers of any owners, corporate officers, partners or members【77455732051001†L145-L154】
Principal business activity performed in Massachusetts and any acquired business information【77455732051001†L145-L154】
Business start date and start date of payroll in Massachusetts
Business physical and mailing addresses
Contact information for owners/officers including titles and Social Security numbers【903911017323593†L151-L166】
IRS 501(c)(3) determination letter for nonprofit organizations【903911017323593†L167-L168】
filing_methods: Register online through the Unemployment Services for Employers portal to obtain a Massachusetts Employer Account Number
Register online through MassTaxConnect to obtain a Massachusetts withholding account number
File quarterly wage and employment reports and pay unemployment contributions through the Unemployment Services for Employers portal
File withholding returns and payments through MassTaxConnect; paper forms are available but online filing is standard
confirmation_proof: Upon completion of registration, the Massachusetts Department of Unemployment Assistance issues an Employer Account Number and contribution rate, and the Department of Revenue issues a Withholding Account Number and deposit frequency notice immediately【963352479712058†L109-L119】.

contacts.phone: 617-626-5075 (Employer customer service for UI) and 877-626-6800 (DUA call center)【719500648356331†L171-L183】; 617-887-6367 (Department of Revenue contact center)【903911017323593†L432-L439】

source_notes: UI liability thresholds and domestic/agricultural categories are taken from the Massachusetts Executive Office of Labor and Workforce Development’s DUA overview and Employer’s Guide, which specify that employers with one or more employees working in 13 weeks or who pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter are liable and that agricultural employers are liable at $40,000 in wages or 10 employees for 20 weeks【436281299933108†L176-L182】【365994320666717†L260-L280】. Required information and registration instructions come from the DUA “Register my Business” page and MassTaxConnect registration guide【77455732051001†L145-L154】【903911017323593†L151-L166】. Processing time and account issuance are confirmed by the Square Support article stating that both the unemployment employer account number and withholding account number are issued immediately upon online registration【963352479712058†L109-L119】.

agency_name: Michigan Unemployment Insurance Agency (UIA)
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,000 or more in payroll within a calendar year or at least one worker employed in 20 different weeks during a calendar year; agricultural employers become liable when cash payroll reaches $20,000 in a quarter or when 10 agricultural workers are employed in 20 weeks; domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in a calendar quarter
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee (general employment); 20 weeks with 10 or more workers (agricultural)
withholding_threshold_description: Every employer maintaining an office or transacting business in Michigan and making payment of compensation to an employee (resident or nonresident) must register for and withhold Michigan income tax from the first payroll; agricultural and domestic services are generally exempt
typical_processing_time: e‑Registration through Michigan’s online system usually completes within a few days and assigns an Employer Account Number; paper applications can take up to six weeks to process
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Date of birth, Social Security number and address of each owner, corporate officer, partner or member
Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) for entities owned by foreign individuals, if applicable
Date of first employment (hiring date) and date on which wage or week liability threshold was met
Whether the business has changed entity type or acquired another business (requiring the EAN and FEIN of the business being acquired, acquisition date and percentage of assets/organization acquired)
Business entity type (sole proprietor, partnership, corporation, LLC, association, government, etc.)
Legal entity name and trade name (DBA)
Date and state of formation
Preferred communication method and contact email
filing_methods: Online e‑Registration via Michigan Business One Stop/MiWAM (preferred)
Paper Form 518 and UIA schedules (Schedule A, Schedule B, etc.) submitted by mail
confirmation_proof: UIA Employer Account Number (EAN) issued along with Form 1183 (Notice of Determination of Employer Status) and Form UIA 1771 (Tax Rate Determination)
source_notes: Michigan liability thresholds and registration requirements

notes: Agricultural and domestic services generally exempt

agency_name: Minnesota Unemployment Insurance Program (Department of Employment and Economic Development) & Minnesota Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: Minnesota does not have a specific wage threshold for unemployment insurance. Any individual or organization that pays covered wages in Minnesota must register for an employer account. Registration should be done as soon as possible after the first wages are paid for covered employment and prior to the due date of the first quarterly wage detail report. Agricultural employers become liable if they pay $20,000 in cash wages in a calendar quarter or employ 10 or more workers in 20 weeks. Non‑profit employers become liable when they employ four or more workers in 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: No minimum number of weeks for general employers; employers register once covered wages are paid. Agricultural employers become liable when they employ 10 or more workers for 20 weeks; non‑profit employers become liable when they have four workers for 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers with employees working in Minnesota must register for a Minnesota Tax ID and withholding account through the Department of Revenue and withhold state income tax from the first payroll, regardless of wages paid.
typical_processing_time: Employers who register online receive their unemployment insurance employer account number and Minnesota Tax ID immediately or within one business day; phone or paper registration may take longer.
required_information: Type of legal entity (corporation, sole proprietorship, LLC, etc.)
Legal name of the entity as registered with the Secretary of State
Doing business as name (if different from legal name)
Physical business address and mailing address
Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Minnesota Department of Revenue Tax ID (if already assigned)
Primary business activity performed in Minnesota
State and date of incorporation (if corporation)
Names, Social Security numbers, home addresses and percentage of ownership for all owners/officers
Whether the business is new or acquired from another entity
Dates covered employees first performed services in Minnesota
Date first wages were paid to covered employees
Number of covered employees in Minnesota
Agent ID (if using a third‑party agent)
filing_methods: Register online through the Employer Self‑Service System at uimn.org to obtain a Minnesota unemployment insurance employer account number.
Alternatively, call 651‑296‑6141 (option 2) to register by phone if internet access is not available.
Register for a Minnesota Tax ID and withholding account through the Minnesota Department of Revenue’s e‑Services (Business Tax Registration) and file/pay withholding taxes through e‑Services.
After registration, file quarterly wage detail reports and pay unemployment contributions through the Employer Self‑Service portal.
confirmation_proof: A confirmation number and employer account number are issued after registration. Employers receive a Minnesota unemployment insurance employer account number and a Minnesota Tax ID (withholding account number).
source_notes: Minnesota UI registration page states that employers must register as soon as possible after paying first wages and lists the information required for registration【226747635388511†L589-L595】【226747635388511†L630-L650】. Patriot Software’s SUTA guide notes that Minnesota has no specific wage threshold and employers must register within 30 days of hiring employees and that the SUTA tax number is issued instantly【225312409300865†L554-L562】.

notes: Registration must occur as soon as wages are paid; there is no minimum wage threshold for general employers.
The Minnesota Department of Revenue requires employers to register for a withholding tax account and withhold state income tax from the first payroll.

agency_name: Mississippi Department of Employment Security (MDES) & Mississippi Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers are liable for Mississippi unemployment insurance tax when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter or when at least one worker performs services on some part of a day in each of 20 different calendar weeks. Agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers for 20 weeks. Domestic (household) employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different calendar weeks with at least one worker for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register with the Mississippi Department of Revenue via the Taxpayer Access Point (TAP) and withhold Mississippi income tax from employees beginning with the first payroll. Registration is required regardless of the amount of wages paid.
typical_processing_time: Online registration generally provides the Mississippi Employer Account Number within 24–48 hours; registering by mail takes about two weeks. Withholding registration via TAP issues an account number once the application is processed (often within a few business days).
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name (if applicable)
Physical business and mailing addresses and phone number
Entity type (corporation, LLC, sole proprietor, etc.) and date formed
Date first wages were paid and total wages paid during the quarter
Number of employees in Mississippi
Names, Social Security numbers and addresses of all owners/officers
Employer type (e.g., agricultural, domestic, nonprofit)
Contact person’s name, phone and email
filing_methods: Register online through the MDES Employer Services portal (accessmstax.mdes.ms.gov) to obtain an unemployment insurance Employer Account Number and pay quarterly contributions.
Alternatively, register by mailing Form UI‑1 to the MDES to establish an employer account.
Register for a withholding account through the Mississippi Department of Revenue’s Taxpayer Access Point (TAP) and file/pay withholding tax through TAP.
Unemployment and withholding taxes can be paid online or by mail (using the appropriate MDES or DOR forms).
confirmation_proof: MDES issues an Employer Account Number and contribution rate letter after registration; the Department of Revenue issues an eight‑digit Mississippi Withholding Account Number and deposit schedule.
source_notes: Patriot Software’s SUTA guide states that Mississippi employers become liable when they pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter or have one worker for 20 weeks and that agricultural employers are liable at $20,000 in wages or 10 workers for 20 weeks; online registration provides a tax number within 24–48 hours【225312409300865†L567-L583】. Square’s Mississippi employer tax information page notes that employers must register with MDES for an Employer Account Number and with the Department of Revenue via the TAP portal to obtain a withholding account number; it lists contact numbers 601‑923‑7088 for withholding and 888‑844‑3577 for unemployment taxes【25058230363081†L48-L56】【25058230363081†L100-L124】.

notes: The Mississippi Department of Revenue requires employers to register and withhold state income tax from employees beginning with the first payroll.

agency_name: Missouri Department of Labor and Industrial Relations – Division of Employment Security & Missouri Department of Revenue
registration_portal_url: https://mytax.mo.gov (Missouri Online Business Registration) and https://uinteract.labor.mo.gov (UI)
ui_wage_threshold_text: A general business becomes liable for Missouri unemployment insurance tax when it pays $1,500 in wages in a calendar quarter or employs a worker for some portion of a day in each of 20 different weeks in a calendar year. Liability may also arise if the employer is subject to FUTA and employs a worker in Missouri or if it acquires a business that was already liable for SUTA.
