Agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 in cash wages in a calendar quarter or employ 10 or more workers for 20 weeks. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one worker for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more workers for nonprofit employers.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers paying wages to employees working in Missouri must register with the Missouri Department of Revenue for a withholding tax account and withhold Missouri income tax from employees beginning with the first payroll.
typical_processing_time: The Missouri Department of Revenue’s online business registration system issues a confirmation number immediately and processes registrations within 2–3 business days. According to Patriot Software, the Missouri Division of Employment Security may take up to one month to assign a Missouri Employer Account Number and contribution rate.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and any trade name (DBA)
Physical and mailing addresses and phone number
Entity type (corporation, LLC, partnership, sole proprietorship, etc.) and date formed
Date of first Missouri payroll and total wages paid in the quarter
Number of employees and type of employment (e.g., agricultural, domestic)
Names, Social Security numbers, addresses and titles of all owners, partners, or corporate officers
Whether the business is new or a successor to an existing Missouri employer
Description of business activity and NAICS code
filing_methods: Register online through the combined Missouri business registration portal at mytax.mo.gov to apply for withholding tax and unemployment insurance tax accounts.
To register an existing account for unemployment insurance, visit the UInteract portal (uinteract.labor.mo.gov) and complete the unemployment tax registration form.
After registration, file and pay unemployment contributions via UInteract and file/pay withholding tax via the MyTax Missouri portal.
confirmation_proof: After registering online, the Missouri Department of Revenue provides a confirmation number and later issues tax registration numbers; the Division of Employment Security mails an employer account number and contribution rate letter.
source_notes: Patriot Software’s SUTA guide explains that Missouri employers become liable when they pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter or employ a worker for part of a day in 20 weeks and notes that employers must notify the state within 30 days of becoming liable and may wait up to one month for their unemployment tax number【225312409300865†L589-L607】. The Missouri Department of Revenue’s online registration page indicates that the combined registration allows employers to apply for withholding and unemployment tax accounts and that a confirmation number is issued immediately with processing taking 2–3 business days【846784382646350†L190-L221】. The Square Payroll article notes that employers must register with both the Department of Revenue and the Division of Employment Security to pay and file taxes and lists contact information【700534703553141†L48-L69】【700534703553141†L125-L153】.

notes: The Missouri Department of Revenue requires employers to register for a withholding account and withhold Missouri income tax from the first payroll.

agency_name: Montana Department of Labor & Industry – Unemployment Insurance Division; Montana Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: General employers become liable for unemployment insurance when total annual payroll reaches $1,000 or more. Agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in any calendar quarter. Domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a calendar quarter【411342499543947†L423-L444】.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Agricultural employers are also liable if they employ 10 or more agricultural workers for some portion of 20 different weeks during a calendar year【411342499543947†L423-L444】. (No specific week‑count threshold for general or domestic employers beyond the wage amounts.)
withholding_threshold_description: Employers who pay wages to employees performing services in Montana or issue Montana W‑2/1099 forms must register for a state income tax withholding account with the Department of Revenue before paying wages【867228617377441†L169-L179】.
typical_processing_time: Employers receive an unemployment insurance account number shortly after completing the online UI eServices registration (typically within a few business days). The Department of Revenue assigns a withholding account number after processing the TransAction Portal or paper Business Registration Form.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name/DBA
Montana physical and mailing addresses
Contact name, phone number and email
Type of ownership and state/date formed (corporation, LLC, partnership, sole proprietorship, etc.)
Type of employment (regular, agricultural, domestic)
Date employees first started working in Montana and date first wages were paid
Total wages paid and estimated number of employees
NAICS code and description of business activity
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners or corporate officers
Information on business acquisitions or mergers and IRS 501(c)(3) exemption letter if applicable
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance online through the UI eServices portal (uieservices.mt.gov)
Register for state income tax withholding online via the TransAction Portal (tap.dor.mt.gov)
Alternatively, mail the Business Registration Form (GenReg) to the Department of Revenue
File quarterly wage and tax reports electronically via UI eServices
confirmation_proof: Montana issues an unemployment insurance account number and contribution rate upon registration. The Department of Revenue mails or provides the withholding account number once the application is processed. Employers should save the confirmation page or email from the UI eServices portal.
source_notes: Montana Employer Handbook details coverage thresholds for general, agricultural and domestic employers【411342499543947†L423-L444】. The UI eServices portal provides employer contact numbers【402625675309573†L138-L144】. The Department of Revenue page explains that employers must register for withholding accounts before paying wages and lists required information【867228617377441†L169-L179】. The Business Registration Form shows fields for business details, FEIN/SSN, addresses, NAICS code and owners/officers【226773428050642†L69-L110】【226773428050642†L169-L180】.

agency_name: Nebraska Department of Labor – Unemployment Insurance Tax; Nebraska Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: General employers become liable when they pay $1,500 or more in gross wages in any calendar quarter【588171141101703†L396-L415】. Domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter【588171141101703†L421-L426】. Agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter【588171141101703†L428-L435】.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Employers become liable if they employ one or more individuals in covered employment for some portion of 20 different weeks in a calendar year【588171141101703†L396-L415】. Agricultural employers are also liable when they employ 10 or more workers in 20 different weeks【588171141101703†L428-L435】. Non‑profit organizations become liable when they have four or more employees in covered employment for 20 different weeks【588171141101703†L439-L447】.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must apply for a Nebraska income tax withholding number before withholding state income taxes from employees. Registration is required when wages subject to Nebraska income tax are paid【266152701493000†L129-L139】.
typical_processing_time: Unemployment tax registrations are reviewed by agency staff and accounts are activated within roughly 24–48 business hours after submission【37818398137271†L510-L518】. The Department of Revenue mails a Nebraska Withholding Certificate with the state identification number after processing Form 20 or the online application.
required_information: Legal business name and physical location
Mailing address
Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Type of organization (sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, LLC, government, nonprofit, etc.)
Type of employment (regular, agricultural, domestic)
Date employees first worked in Nebraska and date first wages were paid
Number of employees and total quarterly payroll
Industry code (NAICS) and description of business activity
Payroll contact information for benefits, unemployment tax and SIDES communications
Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) liability details
Names, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, officers or partners
Information on any acquired business or predecessor account
Details on independent contractors and remote employees
For withholding registration (Form 20): trade name/DBA, accounting period, date of first wages for withholding, and names/SSNs of owners/officers【84236129905932†L69-L110】【84236129905932†L145-L154】
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance online through the NEworks Employer Self Service system
Submit a paper Employer Status Report by mail if unable to register online
Register for income tax withholding online through the Nebraska Department of Revenue’s e-services (NebFile for Business)
Alternatively, mail Form 20 to the Department of Revenue
File quarterly combined tax and wage reports electronically via NEworks or mail Form UI 11T/UI 11W
confirmation_proof: Nebraska sends an Employer Account Number (EAN) and combined tax rate notice after approving the employer registration. For withholding, the Department of Revenue issues a Nebraska Withholding Certificate showing the Nebraska Identification Number. Employers should retain confirmation emails or letters as proof of registration.
source_notes: Nebraska Employer’s Guide to Unemployment Insurance lists wage and week thresholds for general, domestic, agricultural and nonprofit employers【588171141101703†L396-L415】【588171141101703†L421-L426】【588171141101703†L428-L435】【588171141101703†L439-L447】. The Unemployment Tax Account Instructions note that accounts are activated within 24–48 business hours【37818398137271†L510-L518】. The Employer Tax Services User Guide describes required business details, dates of first wages, contact information and ownership details【37818398137271†L339-L350】【37818398137271†L347-L356】. Nebraska Department of Revenue FAQs state that employers must apply for a withholding number using Form 20【266152701493000†L129-L139】; Form 20 requests FEIN/SSN, business name, addresses, NAICS code, date of first wages, and owner/officer information【84236129905932†L69-L110】【84236129905932†L145-L154】.

agency_name: Nevada Department of Employment, Training and Rehabilitation – Employment Security Division (ESD)
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers must register when they pay $225 or more in wages during a calendar quarter【635653378356751†L73-L75】. Agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in any quarter【635653378356751†L78-L80】.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Agricultural employers are liable if they employ 10 or more agricultural workers for at least 20 weeks during a calendar year【635653378356751†L78-L80】. (No explicit week‑threshold applies to general employers beyond the wage requirement.)
withholding_threshold_description: Nevada does not impose a state personal income tax, so employers are not required to register for wage withholding. After UI registration, businesses may need to register for the Modified Business Tax (MBT) if quarterly gross wages exceed $50,000【635653378356751†L46-L58】【635653378356751†L115-L127】.
typical_processing_time: After creating an Employer Self Service (ESS) account on the DETR website and submitting the required information, the Department processes the registration and assigns a Nevada UI account number within approximately 1–3 business days【635653378356751†L97-L110】.
required_information: Legal business name
Federal Employer Identification Number (EIN)
Nevada business license number
Physical and mailing addresses
Contact person’s name, phone number and email
Date payroll will begin or date first wages were paid
Type of business entity and primary business activity (NAICS code)
Number of employees and quarterly gross wages
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance online through the Employer Self Service (ESS) portal at ui.nv.gov
File quarterly Contribution and Wage Reports electronically via the ESS portal
Register for the Modified Business Tax via the Nevada Tax Center after completing UI registration if applicable
confirmation_proof: The Nevada Employment Security Division issues a UI account number after processing the registration. Confirmation is provided via the ESS portal or email. MBT account details are provided separately if applicable.
source_notes: GoCo’s Nevada payroll tax guide notes that registration is required when paying $225 in wages in a quarter and provides agricultural thresholds【635653378356751†L73-L83】. It explains that employers register for unemployment insurance through the Employer Self Service portal and the DETR processes applications within 1–3 business days【635653378356751†L97-L110】. The guide also states that Nevada has no state income tax and that employers must register for the Modified Business Tax only if gross wages exceed $50,000【635653378356751†L46-L58】【635653378356751†L115-L127】. The DETR contact page lists phone numbers for unemployment inquiries【391463858084507†L91-L99】.

agency_name: New Hampshire Employment Security (NHES)
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers become liable when they pay $1,500 or more in wages within a calendar quarter【449766785492033†L59-L61】.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: Employers are also liable if at least one employee performs services for part of a day in 20 or more different weeks during a calendar year【449766785492033†L59-L61】.
withholding_threshold_description: New Hampshire does not levy a state income tax on wages, so employers do not register for wage withholding【449766785492033†L35-L39】【449766785492033†L85-L87】.
typical_processing_time: After registering online through NH Employment Security, employers typically receive their Employer Account Number and unemployment tax rate within about two weeks. Employers needing the number sooner may call NHES the day after registering【449766785492033†L45-L52】.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and mailing address
Physical work address in New Hampshire
Type of business entity and ownership details
Date employees first performed services in New Hampshire and date wages were first paid
Total payroll and number of employees
Contact information for the person responsible for payroll and unemployment correspondence
Names and Social Security numbers of owners, partners or corporate officers
filing_methods: Register online via the NHES Employer WebTax system
File quarterly contribution and wage reports electronically through the WebTax portal
Mail paper reports if electronic filing is not possible
confirmation_proof: NHES issues an Employer Account Number and unemployment tax rate after processing the registration. Employers receive this information by mail and may obtain it sooner by calling NHES. The Letter of Determination or quarterly tax and wage report serves as official confirmation of registration【449766785492033†L71-L80】.
source_notes: Justworks’ New Hampshire payroll tax guide states that employers must register with NHES and are liable when they pay $1,500 in wages or employ at least one employee for part of a week in 20 or more different weeks【449766785492033†L59-L61】. It notes that employers receive their Employer Account Number and tax rate within about two weeks and provides NHES contact phone numbers【449766785492033†L45-L52】【449766785492033†L71-L80】. The guide also clarifies that New Hampshire does not levy state income tax on wages and therefore does not require wage‑withholding registration【449766785492033†L35-L39】【449766785492033†L85-L87】.

agency_name: New Jersey Department of Labor & Workforce Development and Division of Revenue & Enterprise Services
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers become subject to New Jersey unemployment insurance if they employ one or more individuals and pay at least $1,000 in wages in a calendar year. Employers subject to FUTA (employing workers in 20 different weeks or paying $1,500 in wages in a quarter) are automatically liable. Domestic employers are subject when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers when they pay $20,000 in wages in a quarter or employ ten or more workers for 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with one or more workers for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more workers for 501(c)(3) nonprofits; household employment has no weeks test.
withholding_threshold_description: New Jersey requires employers to register for withholding and withhold state income tax from employees' wages whenever federal withholding is required. Employees complete Form NJ‑W4 to determine state withholding; there is no wage threshold.
typical_processing_time: The NJ‑REG must be filed at least 15 business days before commencing business. The Division of Revenue mails a registration confirmation with a 15‑digit employer identification number and a 4‑digit authorization code within about two weeks.
required_information: Business Entity ID or Corporate ID
Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN) or sole proprietor's SSN
NJ Business Code and NAICS code
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses
Names and Social Security numbers of owners, partners or corporate officers
Date of first wages paid in New Jersey and total wages paid
Number of employees
Contact person and email/phone
For S corporations, S corporation registration approval
Line 8 from Form NJ‑927 for employer access (for authorization code)
filing_methods: Online via New Jersey Business Registration (Form NJ‑REG) to register for unemployment insurance, disability, workforce development, and withholding
By mail using Form NJ‑REG to the Division of Revenue & Enterprise Services
Register for Employer Access online to file quarterly wage reports (WR‑30) and contributions (NJ‑927) and obtain the employer identification number and authorization code
confirmation_proof: Employer receives a 15‑digit New Jersey employer identification number (constructed from the FEIN plus a suffix) and a 4‑digit authorization code in a confirmation letter, which serve as the unemployment account number and withholding tax identification; the registration also generates a Notice of Employer Contribution Rate.

contacts.phone: 609‑633‑6400 (Employer Access helpline), 609‑292‑9292 (Division of Revenue business registration)

source_notes: New Jersey Department of Labor Employer Informational Packet and Division of Revenue registration pages describing employer liability and registration requirements. The packet notes that an employing unit with one or more individuals and remuneration of at least $1,000 in a calendar year is an employer; employers subject to FUTA become employers; domestic and agricultural thresholds; the Employer Access instructions page explains the 15‑digit employer ID and 4‑digit authorization code and provides contact information【113854937092216†L26-L55】【918119928763104†L189-L205】. The Division of Taxation page instructs filing NJ‑REG at least 15 days before beginning business【20840840745953†L140-L144】.

notes: Employers subject to FUTA become liable when paying $1,500 in wages in a quarter or having employees for 20 weeks.

agency_name: New Mexico Department of Workforce Solutions (Unemployment Insurance) and New Mexico Taxation & Revenue Department
ui_wage_threshold_text: Non‑agricultural employers must register when their total payroll is $450 or more in a calendar quarter, or if they have one or more workers in any part of 20 weeks in a year. Agricultural employers must register when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers in 20 weeks during the year. Domestic employers must register when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 weeks with one or more workers for non‑agricultural employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more workers for 501(c)(3) nonprofits.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register for a New Mexico Wage Withholding Tax (WWT) account and withhold state income tax whenever they withhold federal income tax from employees; there is no minimum wage threshold for withholding.
typical_processing_time: The New Mexico Taxation & Revenue Department issues a Business Tax Identification Number (BTIN) and deposit schedule on the same day when registration is completed online; the Department of Workforce Solutions assigns an Employer Account Number after reviewing the online application, typically within five to ten business days.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
New Mexico Secretary of State business registration number or CRS number
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and business phone
Type of organization (corporation, LLC, sole proprietor, partnership, nonprofit)
Date employees first performed services and date first wages were or will be paid in New Mexico
Number of employees and estimated quarterly payroll
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and home addresses of owners, partners, or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Whether the business acquired or merged with another company
Wage withholding option and deposit schedule
For nonprofits, 501(c)(3) exemption documentation
filing_methods: Register online for unemployment insurance through the New Mexico Department of Workforce Solutions UI Tax & Claims System (uieservices)

Complete and submit the Employer Registration online for wage withholding through the New Mexico Taxation & Revenue Department's Taxpayer Access Point (TAP) to obtain a Business Tax Identification Number (BTIN)
Mail paper forms if necessary (e.g., Form ACD‑31015 Business Tax Registration) to the Taxation & Revenue Department
confirmation_proof: After registration, the employer receives an Employer Account Number and Contribution Rate Notice from NMDWS and receives a New Mexico Taxation & Revenue Department Business Tax Identification Number and withholding deposit schedule.

contacts.phone: 1‑877‑664‑6984 (NMDWS UI Tax & Claims Customer Service), 505‑827‑0700 (NM Taxation & Revenue Department)

source_notes: New Mexico Unemployment Insurance Employer Handbook lines 239–253 describe the $450 quarterly payroll threshold for non‑agricultural employers, the $20,000 or 10‑worker agricultural threshold, and the $1,000 domestic threshold; the handbook also lists contact details for the UI Tax & Claims system and instructs employers to register online【583426786290834†L239-L253】【583426786290834†L131-L143】. FYI‑104 from the NM Taxation & Revenue Department explains that employers who withhold federal income tax must also withhold New Mexico income tax【241127524021304†L131-L139】. Additional sources (OnPay and Justworks) confirm that the BTIN is issued on the same day and the Employer Account Number is issued within approximately five to ten business days.

agency_name: New York State Department of Labor
ui_wage_threshold_text: $300 or more in remuneration in a calendar quarter for general business employers; nonprofit employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in a quarter or have four or more workers for at least one day in each of 20 weeks; household employers are liable at $500 per quarter; agricultural employers are liable at $300 per quarter (effective Jan 1 2020); governmental entities and Indian tribes are liable from the first dollar of remuneration
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 weeks with four or more employees for nonprofit employers
withholding_threshold_description: Employers who maintain an office or transact business in New York and pay wages to employees must register and withhold New York income tax beginning with the first payroll (withholding is required on wages paid to residents and on wages paid to nonresidents for services performed in New York)
typical_processing_time: Registration through New York Business Express generally yields an employer registration number within a few days; paper Form NYS‑100 filings may take longer
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Type of legal entity and structure (corporation, partnership, sole proprietor, etc.)
Telephone and fax numbers
Legal name and trade name (DBA) of the business
Business email address
Date the business began operations in New York and date first payroll was paid
Number of covered employees
Whether the business expects to pay $300 or more in a calendar quarter or have employees for 20 weeks
Whether the business is registering for unemployment insurance, withholding only, or both
Information on any acquisition of a prior business (name, employer registration number and date of acquisition)
Physical, mailing and record‑keeping addresses and contact person
filing_methods: Online via New York Business Express (NYBE) for most general, household and agricultural employers
Paper Form NYS‑100 (Business Unemployment Insurance Registration) for nonprofit organizations, government employers and Indian tribes
confirmation_proof: Eight‑digit employer registration number assigned by the Department of Labor and confirmation letter
source_notes: NY DOL liability thresholds and registration instructions

notes: Governmental entities and Indian tribes liable from first dollar

agency_name: North Carolina Division of Employment Security (DES)
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in wages in a quarter or at least one worker in covered employment for 20 different weeks during a calendar year; domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 or more in a quarter; nonprofit 501(c)(3) employers become liable when they have four or more employees for 20 weeks; agricultural employers become liable when they pay $20,000 in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers for 20 weeks
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee (general employment); 20 weeks with four or more employees (nonprofit) or with 10 or more workers (agricultural)
withholding_threshold_description: Employers paying wages to individuals for services performed in North Carolina must register for and withhold state income tax from the first payroll; Form NC‑BR can be filed online or on paper to obtain a North Carolina withholding identification number
typical_processing_time: Employers who register online through the North Carolina State Unemployment Insurance Tax System receive an Employer ID Number immediately; paper Employer Status Report (NCUI‑604) processing time is longer; the Department of Revenue mails the withholding identification number after processing Form NC‑BR
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal name and trade name (if any) of the business
Business entity type (corporation, partnership, sole proprietor, etc.)
Dates of first service performed in North Carolina and first wages paid
Number of employees and whether the business expects to meet wage or week thresholds
Information on whether the employer is a nonprofit, agricultural, domestic or governmental entity
Details about acquisitions or changes of ownership
Business mailing, physical and record‑keeping addresses and contact person
filing_methods: Online via NCSUITS (Employer Self‑Service Portal)
Paper Employer Status Report (Form NCUI‑604) for unemployment tax and paper Form NC‑BR for withholding tax
confirmation_proof: Employer ID Number for unemployment tax and a separate North Carolina withholding identification number mailed by the Department of Revenue
source_notes: DES liability thresholds and withholding registration instructions

agency_name: Job Service North Dakota and North Dakota Office of State Tax Commissioner
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers become liable for North Dakota unemployment insurance when they pay $1,500 or more in gross wages during a calendar quarter or have one or more individuals in employment for any part of a day in 20 different weeks within a calendar year. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers in agricultural labor for 20 weeks; nonprofit employers with 501(c)(3) status become liable when they employ four or more workers for some portion of a day in 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more employees for 501(c)(3) nonprofits.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register for a North Dakota income tax withholding account via the Taxpayer Access Point before withholding state income tax; withholding is required on wages paid to employees performing services in North Dakota when federal income tax must be withheld; there is no minimum wage threshold.
typical_processing_time: Employers are required to submit a Report to Determine Liability within 20 days of hiring employees or acquiring a business; after the report is processed, the unemployment insurance account number is issued, typically within one to two weeks; the Tax Commissioner usually issues the withholding account number within a few days of online registration.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and business phone number
Type of ownership (corporation, LLC, partnership, sole proprietor, nonprofit) and date formed
Date employees first performed services and date first wages were paid in North Dakota
Estimated quarterly payroll and number of covered employees
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of all owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Information about acquisitions or mergers and successor employer details
Payroll contact person and email
For nonprofits, proof of 501(c)(3) status
filing_methods: File a Report to Determine Liability online through Job Service North Dakota's UI EASY portal or submit Form SFN 41216 by mail within 20 days after hiring employees; once liability is established, employers may file quarterly contribution reports electronically via UI EASY
Register for an income tax withholding account using the Taxpayer Access Point (TAP) on the Office of State Tax Commissioner’s website; employers may also complete the paper application if needed
confirmation_proof: After successful registration, the employer receives a North Dakota unemployment insurance account number and rate notice from Job Service North Dakota and a withholding account number from the Office of State Tax Commissioner.

contacts.phone: 701‑328‑2814 (Job Service North Dakota UI Tax), 701‑328‑1241 (Office of State Tax Commissioner)

source_notes: The North Dakota Employer's Handbook lists the liability criteria: paying $1,500 or more in wages or having one or more individuals in employment for any part of 20 different weeks; domestic and agricultural thresholds ($1,000 cash wages, $20,000 or 10 workers) and a rule for 501(c)(3) nonprofits【675404955639916†L628-L707】. The handbook also explains that employers must submit a Report to Determine Liability within 20 days of hiring employees【675404955639916†L630-L647】. A Square article states that employers need both a North Dakota UI account and a North Dakota withholding account and provides contact phone numbers for the Job Service North Dakota and the State Tax Commissioner【289978958769971†L51-L148】.

agency_name: Ohio Department of Job and Family Services (ODJFS)
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter or at least one employee in covered employment for 20 different weeks; domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 in cash wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more individuals for 20 weeks; nonprofit employers become liable when they have four or more employees for 20 weeks; governmental entities and Indian tribes are liable from the first dollar of remuneration
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee (general employment); 20 weeks with four or more employees (nonprofit); 20 weeks with 10 or more workers (agricultural)
withholding_threshold_description: Every employer maintaining an office or transacting business in Ohio and paying compensation to an employee (resident or nonresident) must register within 15 days of liability and withhold Ohio income tax from the first payroll, unless the employee is a resident of a reciprocal state (MI, IN, KY, WV or PA)
typical_processing_time: Online registration via The SOURCE yields an Employer ID and contribution rate immediately; paper Report to Determine Liability (JFS 20100) takes approximately 4–6 weeks to process
required_information: Contact person’s name, job title, address, telephone number and email
Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Dates work was first performed in Ohio and the first covered wages were paid
Number of employees currently paid or expected to be paid
Business type (regular, nonprofit, agricultural, domestic, public entity)
Whether the employer expects to meet the wage or week liability thresholds
Employer entity type (sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, LLC, association, government entity, etc.)
Legal entity name and trade name (DBA)
Date and state of formation
Whether the employer acquired all or part of an existing business (with details: employer account number and FEIN of predecessor, date and percentage of acquisition)
Preferred method of communication (email or postal mail)
filing_methods: Online via The SOURCE (preferred)
Paper Report to Determine Liability (Form JFS 20100) mailed to ODJFS
confirmation_proof: Employer ID number and contribution rate notice provided electronically after online registration or mailed after paper processing
source_notes: ODJFS liability criteria and registration information

notes: Governmental entities and Indian tribes liable from first dollar
Reciprocal state exemptions (MI, IN, KY, WV, PA)

agency_name: Oklahoma Employment Security Commission (OESC) and Oklahoma Tax Commission
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers must report wages and pay Oklahoma unemployment insurance taxes when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter or have employment in any part of a day in each of 20 different weeks in a year. Agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers in agricultural labor for 20 weeks. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter. Non‑profit organizations become liable when they employ four or more workers for 20 weeks. Successor employers, employers subject to FUTA and out‑of‑state employers paying wages in Oklahoma are also liable.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with one or more employees for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more employees for 501(c)(3) nonprofits.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register with the Oklahoma Tax Commission for a withholding account and withhold Oklahoma income tax from wages paid to employees; there is no minimum wage threshold—registration is required when employees are first hired and wages are paid in Oklahoma.
typical_processing_time: Account numbers are typically issued within a few business days after completing the online application through EZ Tax Express and the Taxpayer Access Point; employers registering by mail may wait several weeks.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and any trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and business phone number
Ownership type and date of organization
Date employees first worked in Oklahoma and date first wages were paid
Estimated quarterly payroll and number of employees
Names, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity or NAICS code
Information about predecessors or acquired businesses
Payroll contact person’s name, email and phone
For non‑profits, proof of 501(c)(3) status
filing_methods: Register for an Oklahoma unemployment account online using the EZ Tax Express portal (create a user ID and submit a status report) or mail a paper OESC Employer Registration form
Register for a withholding tax account online through the Oklahoma Tax Commission’s Taxpayer Access Point (OTAP) or submit Form BT‑190 with the Commission
After registration, file quarterly contribution reports and wage reports electronically via EZ Tax Express and file withholding tax returns via OTAP.
confirmation_proof: The Oklahoma Employment Security Commission sends an Employer Account Number and tax rate notice upon completion of the status report; the Oklahoma Tax Commission issues a withholding account number and deposit schedule after registration.

contacts.phone: 405‑557‑7100 (OESC main), 405‑557‑5452 (EZ Tax Express help desk), 405‑521‑3160 (Oklahoma Tax Commission Taxpayer Assistance)

source_notes: The Oklahoma EZ Tax Express page explains that employers must report wages and pay unemployment insurance taxes when they have employment in 20 weeks or pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter; it notes additional thresholds for agricultural and domestic employers and nonprofits and lists contact numbers【144351340753837†L31-L45】【144351340753837†L57-L79】. The GoCo payroll tax guide states that employers must register with the Oklahoma Tax Commission via the Taxpayer Access Point for withholding and with the OESC for unemployment, provides required information and notes that account numbers are issued within a few business days【241789649166329†L117-L137】.

notes: Employers subject to FUTA or who succeed liable employers are covered.

agency_name: Oregon Employment Department and Oregon Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: A non‑agricultural employer becomes subject to Oregon unemployment tax when total payroll reaches $1,000 or more in any calendar quarter or when the employer has one or more employees in each of 18 separate weeks within a year. Agricultural employers become subject when they pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter or when they employ 10 or more workers for some part of a day in each of 20 weeks in a year. Domestic employers are subject when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 18 separate weeks with at least one employee for non‑agricultural employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more employees for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more employees for nonprofit 501(c)(3) organizations; there is no weeks test for domestic employers.
withholding_threshold_description: Oregon requires employers to register for a Business Identification Number (BIN) and withhold state income tax on all wages paid to employees; there is no wage threshold. Employers must register before issuing paychecks.
typical_processing_time: Online registration for a Business Identification Number through Revenue Online typically takes around 30 business days; submitting the paper Combined Employer Registration form by mail can take 60 days. The Employment Department issues the unemployment account number after processing the Combined Employer Registration.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name (DBA)
Business mailing and physical addresses, phone number and email
Type of ownership and date and state of formation
Date employees were or will be first paid in Oregon and date payroll will exceed $1,000 in a quarter (or $20,000 for agricultural labor)
Estimated number of employees and quarterly payroll
North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code and detailed description of business activity
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of all owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Banking information and payroll contact person
Acquisition or successor information
For nonprofit entities, copy of the 501(c)(3) exemption
filing_methods: Complete the Combined Employer Registration form (OR‑CER) online via Oregon’s Revenue Online system to obtain a Business Identification Number and unemployment account number
Mail the paper Combined Employer Registration to the Oregon Department of Revenue if not registering online
Use Oregon’s I‑Tax/OTTER or OED Employer Login to submit quarterly wage reports and unemployment contributions
File withholding returns and pay taxes electronically using the Revenue Online portal.
confirmation_proof: After registration, the Oregon Employment Department sends an employer account number and state unemployment tax rate notice; the Department of Revenue sends a Business Identification Number and confirmation letter.

contacts.phone: 503‑947‑1488 (Oregon Employment Department UI tax information), 503‑945‑8091 or 503‑378‑4988 (Oregon Department of Revenue payroll tax assistance)

source_notes: The Oregon Employer’s Guide explains that general employers are subject to unemployment tax when they pay $1,000 or more in a quarter or employ workers in 18 separate weeks; agricultural employers are subject when they pay $20,000 or more or employ 10 workers in 20 weeks; domestic employers are subject when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages【538434974599010†L633-L646】. The Combined Employer Registration form lists required information such as FEIN, legal name, NAICS code, addresses, owners’ Social Security numbers, and dates of first payroll【413868984517124†L15-L79】. The Department of Revenue’s withholding and payroll tax page states that employers must register for a Business Identification Number before paying wages, that online registrations take 30 business days, and that paper submissions can take 60 days【902914791521361†L51-L60】. The Employer’s Guide emphasises that withholding must be deducted from all wages and provides telephone numbers for assistance【940578917330614†L64-L70】. The U.S. Department of Labor contact list provides UI tax assistance numbers【48761910951811†L348-L357】.

agency_name: Pennsylvania Department of Labor & Industry (Office of Unemployment Compensation Tax Services) and Pennsylvania Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: In Pennsylvania any employer who pays wages to employees must register for unemployment compensation; there is no minimum payroll or weeks threshold. Employers are covered as soon as wages are paid, and employers subject to FUTA are automatically liable. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter; agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a quarter or employ at least 10 workers in 20 weeks; nonprofit employers become liable when they employ four or more workers for 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: There is no weeks test for general employers (coverage begins as soon as wages are paid); agricultural employers have a 20‑week test requiring 10 workers; 501(c)(3) nonprofits become liable when they employ four or more workers for 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register for employer withholding via Pennsylvania’s myPATH system and withhold personal income tax on wages paid to resident employees and nonresident employees working in Pennsylvania; there is no minimum wage threshold.
typical_processing_time: After completing the online registration through myPATH and the UC Employer Portal, employers typically receive their Pennsylvania employer account numbers within a few weeks (generally two to four weeks) by mail.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and phone number
Type of legal entity and date of incorporation or formation
Date employees were first hired and date first wages were paid in Pennsylvania
Estimated number of employees and quarterly wages
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Whether the business acquired another Pennsylvania employer or changed ownership
Payroll contact person and email address
Banking information for electronic payments
filing_methods: Register online through the Pennsylvania Office of Unemployment Compensation Tax Services (UCMS) or Employer UC Services for You (e‑Services) to obtain a UC account number
Register via the Pennsylvania Department of Revenue’s myPATH portal for employer withholding and other taxes
Submit paper Forms PA‑100 or UC‑1608N if online registration is not possible
File quarterly contribution and wage reports electronically and remit withholding tax through myPATH
confirmation_proof: Employers receive a Pennsylvania Unemployment Compensation employer account number and contribution rate notice from the Department of Labor & Industry and a withholding account number and deposit schedule from the Department of Revenue.

contacts.phone: 717‑787‑7679 (Office of Unemployment Compensation Tax Services), 717‑787‑1064 (Department of Revenue Customer Experience Center)

source_notes: The U.S. Department of Labor’s comparative table shows that Pennsylvania does not impose a minimum payroll or weeks threshold for employer coverage; employers become liable as soon as wages are paid【157654199418392†L178-L180】. Additional sources note that employers should register when they pay $1,500 in wages or have an employee for 20 weeks, but the threshold is effectively any wage payment【314840177766826†L72-L91】. The Department of Revenue’s Employer Withholding Information guide explains that employers register for withholding through myPATH and must withhold Pennsylvania personal income tax from wages【258570377914066†L96-L104】.

agency_name: Rhode Island Department of Labor and Training (DLT) and Rhode Island Division of Taxation
ui_wage_threshold_text: With few exceptions, employers of one or more workers in Rhode Island are subject to the Employment Security Act and must contribute to the unemployment insurance and temporary disability insurance programs. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in any calendar quarter. Agricultural labor is covered regardless of wages. 501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations become liable when they have four or more workers.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: General employers are covered immediately upon having employees; there is no weeks test. Nonprofit employers become liable when they employ four or more workers for some portion of a day in 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Rhode Island requires employers to withhold state income tax from wages paid to employees; there is no minimum threshold, and employers register for withholding through the combined online registration system or by filing a Business Application and Registration (BAR) form.
typical_processing_time: Once the determination of tax liability is filed, the Department assigns a Rhode Island employer registration number and sends a Registration Certificate and Notice to Employees (Form TX‑6). According to the Business Application and Registration instructions, unemployment accounts are set up within 90 days of the liability date or the first wages paid.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN) or Social Security number
Legal business name and trade name (DBA)
Mailing and physical addresses and contact phone
Type of entity and state/date of incorporation or formation
Rhode Island work location(s) and expected number of employees
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, or corporate officers
Estimated quarterly payroll and first date wages were paid in Rhode Island
Contact person for payroll, sales tax and unemployment matters (name, phone, email)
Business activity and NAICS code
For nonprofits, copy of IRS determination letter (501(c)(3)).
filing_methods: Register online through the Rhode Island Division of Taxation’s combined Online Business Registration system to obtain income tax withholding and unemployment insurance accounts
Submit the paper Business Application and Registration (BAR) form to the Division of Taxation for combined registration if online filing is not possible
Employers also file a Determination of Tax Liability with the Department of Labor & Training to determine whether they are subject to unemployment insurance.
confirmation_proof: The Division of Taxation issues a Rhode Island employer identification number upon registration and sends a Registration Certificate (TX‑6) and Notice to Employees; the Department of Labor & Training assigns an unemployment insurance account number and contribution rate after liability is determined.

contacts.phone: 401‑574‑8700 (DLT Employer Tax Section), 401‑574‑8938 (Division of Taxation Registration Section)

source_notes: The Rhode Island Employer Handbook states that, with few exceptions, employers of one or more workers are subject to the Employment Security and Temporary Disability Insurance Acts; domestic employers become subject at $1,000 of cash wages per quarter and new employers must submit a determination of tax liability to the Department of Labor & Training, which issues a registration certificate and notice【201101578072636†L148-L275】. The online Employer Registration page from the Division of Taxation explains that employers can register for income tax withholding and unemployment insurance simultaneously and provides contact phone numbers【743889285801067†L21-L49】. The Business Application and Registration form notes that the unemployment account will be set up within 90 days of the liability date or first wages paid and lists required information【171686917132981†L168-L174】.

agency_name: South Carolina Department of Employment and Workforce (DEW) and South Carolina Department of Revenue
ui_wage_threshold_text: A business becomes liable for South Carolina unemployment tax contributions when it pays $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter or has at least one employee during any part of 20 weeks in a calendar year. Agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers in agricultural labor for a day in 20 weeks. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter. Non‑profit employers with 501(c)(3) status become liable when they employ four or more individuals during 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 weeks with at least one employee for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more workers for non‑profit employers.
withholding_threshold_description: South Carolina employers must register for a withholding file number and withhold state income tax from employees’ wages whenever federal withholding applies; there is no minimum wage threshold.
typical_processing_time: When registering online via MyDORWAY, the Department of Revenue issues the withholding file number and deposit schedule within 24 hours; paper applications may take up to three weeks. The Department of Employment and Workforce assigns the unemployment account number via the SUITS portal in approximately two to three weeks.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses
Type of business entity and date formed
Date employees first worked in South Carolina and date first wages were paid
Quarterly wages and number of employees
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Email address and phone number of payroll contact
Information on any predecessor businesses or acquisitions
For nonprofits, documentation of 501(c)(3) status.
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance online through the South Carolina Department of Employment and Workforce’s SUITS portal or submit a paper Employer Status Report
Register for a withholding file number via the South Carolina Department of Revenue’s MyDORWAY Business Tax Application or mail Form WH‑1601
File quarterly contribution and wage reports electronically through SUITS and remit withholding tax and returns through MyDORWAY or by mail.
confirmation_proof: The Department of Employment and Workforce issues an unemployment insurance employer account number and tax rate letter upon approval. The Department of Revenue sends a South Carolina withholding file number and deposit schedule once registration is processed.
source_notes: The South Carolina Department of Employment and Workforce’s Employer Resources page states that employers are liable for unemployment tax when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in a quarter or have at least one employee during 20 weeks; it lists additional thresholds for domestic ($1,000 in cash wages), agricultural ($20,000 or 10 workers), and non‑profits (four workers) and provides the Employer Status Section contact number【281459519241236†L249-L259】【281459519241236†L331-L334】【281459519241236†L309-L310】. A Justworks article explains that the South Carolina Department of Revenue issues the withholding file number within 24 hours of online registration or up to three weeks by mail and that the Department of Employment and Workforce assigns the unemployment account number in two to three weeks【772275452684993†L46-L99】.

agency_name: South Dakota Department of Labor & Regulation – Reemployment Assistance Division
ui_wage_threshold_text: South Dakota employers must register for reemployment assistance when they pay $1,500 or more in wages in a calendar quarter or employ at least one worker for some part of a day in each of 20 different weeks during a calendar year. Non‑profit organizations must register when they have employees for 20 weeks; there is no wage threshold for nonprofits. Employers who acquire or succeed a liable business must register within 30 days. Agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a quarter or have 10 or more workers for 20 weeks. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with one or more employees for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks for non‑profit organizations with four or more workers.
withholding_threshold_description: South Dakota does not levy a state income tax; employers are not required to register for or withhold state income tax.
typical_processing_time: Employers can register online or by mail; account numbers are generally assigned within a few business days when registering online and may take longer by mail.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and phone
Date employees first performed services in South Dakota and date first wages were paid
Estimated quarterly payroll and number of employees
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Information on predecessor business or acquisition
Payroll contact person and email
Whether the employer is a non‑profit, government, agricultural or domestic employer.
filing_methods: Register online through the South Dakota Reemployment Assistance Employer Portal or submit the Employer's Application for Reemployment Assistance Account (Form UI‑1) by mail
Once registered, file quarterly wage reports and remit contributions electronically or by mail using forms provided by the Department.
confirmation_proof: The South Dakota Department of Labor & Regulation issues a Reemployment Assistance account number and contribution rate notice once registration is approved.
source_notes: A GoCo payroll tax guide explains that South Dakota employers must register for reemployment assistance when they pay $1,500 in wages in a quarter or employ a worker for 20 separate weeks; non‑profits register after 20 weeks and there is no state income tax【188797999901365†L88-L97】. The same guide notes that registration can be completed online or via paper forms and emphasises that successor employers must register within 30 days【188797999901365†L88-L97】.

notes: Non‑profit employers register after 20 weeks regardless of wages.

agency_name: Tennessee Department of Labor and Workforce Development – Division of Employment Security
ui_wage_threshold_text: Employers become liable for Tennessee unemployment insurance premiums if they pay total wages of $1,500 or more in any calendar quarter or employ one or more persons during some part of a day in each of 20 different weeks during the current or preceding calendar year. Employers who succeed a liable employer or who are subject to FUTA are also liable. Agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a calendar quarter or employ 10 or more persons in agricultural labor for 20 weeks. Domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter. Non‑profit employers with 501(c)(3) status are liable when they employ four or more workers for part of a day in 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with one or more employees for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more employees for 501(c)(3) nonprofits.
withholding_threshold_description: Tennessee does not impose a state income tax on wages; therefore employers are not required to register for or withhold state income tax.
typical_processing_time: Employers must apply for an employer account number as soon as they meet liability conditions; the Department of Labor and Workforce Development usually issues the unemployment account number within a few business days after the application is filed.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and phone number
Type of ownership and date of formation
Date employees first performed services and date first wages were paid in Tennessee
Total payroll for the quarter and number of employees
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Information about acquisitions or successor relationships
Whether the business is agricultural, domestic, or nonprofit
Payroll contact person and email
filing_methods: Register online through the Tennessee Department of Labor Employer Services portal or file the Employer’s Application for Account Number (Form LB‑0441) by mail
File quarterly wage and premium reports electronically through TNPAWS or by mail after registration.
confirmation_proof: The Tennessee Department of Labor and Workforce Development issues an Employer Account Number and contribution rate notice upon approval of the registration.
source_notes: The Tennessee Employer Handbook explains that an employer becomes liable if it pays $1,500 or more in total payroll in any calendar quarter or employs one or more persons for some part of a day in 20 weeks; the same section notes that agricultural employers are liable if they pay $20,000 or more in wages or employ 10 or more workers, that domestic employers are liable at $1,000 in cash wages, and that nonprofits with 4 employees for 20 weeks are covered【924893968000194†L1238-L1276】. Earlier sections of the handbook provide toll‑free and out‑of‑state contact numbers for employer accounts【924893968000194†L44-L47】. Tennessee has no state income tax, so employers are not required to register for withholding【530496491059370†L14-L23】.

agency_name: Texas Workforce Commission (TWC)
ui_wage_threshold_text: $1,500 in total gross wages in a calendar quarter or one employee working in 20 different weeks in a calendar year; domestic employers become liable at $1,000 in wages and agricultural employers become liable when they pay $6,250 in wages in a quarter or have three or more workers for 20 weeks
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee (general employment)
withholding_threshold_description: Texas does not have a state income tax, so no state wage‑withholding account is required for employees
typical_processing_time: Account numbers are issued immediately when registering online; paper Form C‑1 filings take longer
required_information: Business contact email address
Date of first Texas hire and first wages paid
Total gross wages for the first quarter of employment
Name, Social Security number and address for each owner, partner or corporate officer
Current U.S. mailing address and physical location of each business site
Trade name (DBA) for each business location
Description of principal business activities
Information on any acquisition of a prior business (name, address and employer account number of predecessor)
filing_methods: Online via Unemployment Tax Registration (UTR)
Paper Employer Status Report (Form C‑1) if unable to file online
confirmation_proof: Immediate assignment of a TWC unemployment tax account number and confirmation letter
source_notes: TWC liability criteria and registration information

notes: Texas has no state income tax

agency_name: Utah Department of Workforce Services and Utah State Tax Commission
ui_wage_threshold_text: Under Utah’s Employment Security Act, any employer who pays wages to one or more individuals in covered employment is liable for unemployment taxes; there is no minimum wage amount. Employers are considered liable if they employ one or more individuals for some portion of a day in each of 20 different weeks during a calendar year or become liable under the Federal Unemployment Tax Act. Agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers in agricultural labor for 20 weeks. Domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with one or more workers for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more employees for 501(c)(3) nonprofits.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register with the Utah State Tax Commission and the Department of Workforce Services to withhold Utah income tax from employees’ wages; there is no minimum wage threshold. Employers must register within 30 days of paying wages in Utah; an exemption applies if the employer operated in Utah for 60 days or less in a calendar year.
typical_processing_time: Utah’s Taxpayer Access Point allows employers to register for both payroll tax withholding and unemployment insurance accounts in a single online process; account numbers for withholding and unemployment insurance are typically issued immediately after submission.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and phone number
Type of business entity and date of formation
Date employees first worked in Utah and date first wages were or will be paid
Estimated quarterly payroll and number of employees in Utah
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of all owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Whether the employer is agricultural, domestic, or nonprofit and any federal FUTA liability
Payroll contact person and email address.
filing_methods: Register online through the Utah Taxpayer Access Point (TAP) to obtain both a withholding tax account and an unemployment insurance account
File quarterly wage and contribution reports through the Department of Workforce Services’ Employer Portal (jobs.utah.gov)
Submit paper registration forms if online filing is not available.
confirmation_proof: After registration through TAP, the employer receives both a Utah withholding account number and an Unemployment Insurance Employer Registration Number (employer account number) along with a notice of the assigned tax rate.

contacts.phone: 801‑526‑9400 (Department of Workforce Services Employer Accounts), 801‑297‑2200 (Utah State Tax Commission general information)

source_notes: The Utah UI Employer training publication lists the coverage criteria: any employer who has employed one or more individuals for some portion of a day in each of 20 different weeks, agricultural employers who pay $20,000 or more or have 10 or more workers, domestic employers who pay $1,000 in wages, and employers subject to FUTA【856378681411930†L79-L94】. A GoCo payroll tax guide states that employers paying wages in Utah must register with both the State Tax Commission and the Department of Workforce Services, regardless of wage amount, and that account numbers are issued through the Taxpayer Access Point【601780587843100†L45-L112】.

notes: Employers operating in Utah for 60 days or less may not be required to register.

agency_name: Vermont Department of Labor (VDOL) and Vermont Department of Taxes
ui_wage_threshold_text: According to the U.S. Department of Labor’s comparative analysis of unemployment laws, Vermont’s definition of employer does not include a minimum payroll or weeks threshold; employers become liable for unemployment insurance contributions as soon as they pay wages. Agricultural labor coverage follows the federal FUTA thresholds: employers are liable if they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers for some part of a day in 20 weeks. Domestic employers become liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter. 501(c)(3) nonprofit employers become liable when they employ four or more workers for some part of 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: There is no weeks test for general employers (coverage begins when wages are paid); agricultural employers have a 20‑week test requiring 10 workers; non‑profit employers become liable when they employ four or more workers in 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register for a Vermont income tax withholding account through myVTax and withhold state income tax from wages paid to Vermont residents and nonresidents working in Vermont; registration is required when wages are first paid (no minimum threshold).
typical_processing_time: Registration for unemployment and withholding via the Vermont Department of Labor and Department of Taxes online systems typically provides account numbers within a few business days; paper applications may take longer.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN) or Social Security number
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses
Type of legal entity and date formed
Date employees first performed services in Vermont and date first wages were paid
Estimated number of employees and quarterly payroll
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Information on prior Vermont employer account numbers or predecessor businesses
Contact person and email/phone
filing_methods: Register online for unemployment insurance through the Vermont Department of Labor’s myUI Employer portal; employers may mail paper registration forms if necessary
Register for a Vermont withholding tax account via the Department of Taxes’ myVTax portal or by mail
After registration, file quarterly wage and contribution reports electronically through the myUI Employer portal and file withholding returns through myVTax.
confirmation_proof: The Vermont Department of Labor sends an Employer Account Number and contribution rate notice for unemployment insurance; the Department of Taxes issues a Vermont Account Number and deposit schedule for withholding.
source_notes: The U.S. Department of Labor comparative analysis of state unemployment insurance laws notes that Vermont does not set a minimum payroll or weeks threshold for employer coverage, meaning coverage applies as soon as wages are paid【157654199418392†L165-L180】. Additional U.S. Department of Labor tables state that agricultural labor is covered when wages reach $20,000 in a quarter or 10 workers for 20 weeks and domestic employers are covered when they pay $1,000 in cash wages【157654199418392†L205-L210】【157654199418392†L328-L331】. State guidance from the Department of Taxes requires employers to register for withholding and withhold Vermont income tax on wages whenever employees are paid.

agency_name: Virginia Employment Commission and Virginia Department of Taxation
ui_wage_threshold_text: For‑profit employers are liable for Virginia unemployment tax if they pay wages of $1,500 or more in a calendar quarter or have at least one employee for some part of a day in each of 20 weeks in a calendar year, or if they are subject to the Federal Unemployment Tax Act. Domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter. 501(c)(3) non‑profit organizations are liable if they employ four or more individuals in each of 20 weeks; such nonprofits are exempt if they have fewer than four employees. Agricultural employers are covered under the general FUTA thresholds ($20,000 in wages or 10 workers for 20 weeks).
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more workers for nonprofit employers; no weeks test for domestic employers.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register with the Virginia Department of Taxation for an employer withholding tax account and withhold state income tax from wages paid to employees; registration is required from the first payroll if wages are subject to federal withholding.
typical_processing_time: Employers can register online using the Virginia iReg system and receive a Virginia Employment Commission (VEC) account number immediately; registration with the Department of Taxation through the Business Online Services portal issues a withholding account number and tax payment schedule within a few business days.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and phone
Type of legal entity and date of formation
Date employees first performed services in Virginia and date first wages were paid
Estimated number of employees and quarterly payroll
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of all owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Information on predecessor or successor businesses
Payroll contact person and email
For nonprofit employers, 501(c)(3) determination letter.
filing_methods: Register online via the Virginia Employment Commission’s iReg portal to obtain a VEC employer account number for unemployment insurance or complete the VEC‑FC‑27 paper form and mail it to the VEC
Register for a withholding account through the Virginia Department of Taxation’s Business Online Services or by filing Form R‑1
File quarterly contribution and wage reports electronically through iReg and remit withholding tax through the Department of Taxation’s eForms or eFile programs.
confirmation_proof: The Virginia Employment Commission provides an employer account number and tax rate immediately after iReg registration; the Department of Taxation sends a Virginia employer withholding account number and deposit schedule after processing.

contacts.phone: 804‑786‑3061 (VEC Employer Tax Unit), 804‑367‑8037 (Department of Taxation business registration)

source_notes: The Virginia Employment Commission’s Employer UI Tax FAQ states that employers are liable for unemployment tax if they have a quarterly payroll of $1,500 or more or have an employee for 20 weeks; domestic employers are liable at $1,000 in cash wages; 501(c)(3) nonprofits are exempt if they have fewer than four employees and become liable at four employees【580301483809527†L63-L74】【580301483809527†L82-L90】【580301483809527†L103-L110】. The FAQ notes that employers can register via iReg and receive a VEC account number immediately. Agricultural thresholds follow the federal standard.

agency_name: Washington Employment Security Department
ui_wage_threshold_text: Under Washington law, employers become subject to unemployment insurance taxes as soon as they pay wages to employees; there is no minimum payroll or weeks threshold. Employers subject to FUTA or employing domestic or agricultural workers are also liable, with agricultural coverage applying when wages reach $20,000 in a quarter or 10 workers in 20 weeks and domestic coverage applying at $1,000 in cash wages in a quarter.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: No weeks test for general employers; agricultural employers are covered when they employ 10 or more workers for 20 weeks; nonprofit employers are covered when they employ four or more workers for 20 weeks.
withholding_threshold_description: Washington does not levy a state income tax on wages, so employers are not required to register for or withhold state income tax; however, employers must register for unemployment insurance and Paid Family & Medical Leave.
typical_processing_time: The Employment Security Department’s Employer Account Management Services portal assigns an unemployment insurance account number when registration is completed; account activation generally occurs within a few business days.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Unified Business Identifier (UBI) if registered with the Washington Secretary of State
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and contact phone
Type of business entity and date of formation
Date employees first performed services in Washington and date first wages were paid
Estimated quarterly payroll and number of employees
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Information on predecessor or successor businesses
Payroll contact person and email
filing_methods: Register online through the Employment Security Department’s Employer Account Management Services portal to obtain an unemployment insurance account number
Complete paper forms (e.g., Employer Account Application) if online registration is not available
File quarterly wage reports and pay unemployment taxes electronically through the employer portal
Register with the Department of Labor & Industries for workers’ compensation and with the Employment Security Department for Paid Family & Medical Leave, if applicable.
confirmation_proof: The Employment Security Department sends an Employer Account Number and contribution rate notice once registration is processed.
source_notes: The U.S. Department of Labor’s comparative analysis of state unemployment insurance laws lists Washington among states where employer coverage applies immediately (there is no minimum payroll or weeks requirement)【157654199418392†L165-L180】. The same analysis notes that agricultural labor is covered at $20,000 in wages or 10 workers and that domestic service is covered when cash wages reach $1,000【157654199418392†L205-L210】【157654199418392†L328-L331】. Washington has no state income tax, so withholding registration is not required.

notes: No state income tax; employers may need to register for Paid Family & Medical Leave.

agency_name: WorkForce West Virginia and West Virginia State Tax Department
ui_wage_threshold_text: Under West Virginia law, an employing unit becomes an employer when, in any calendar quarter, it pays wages of $1,500 or more for services in employment, or when it employs at least one individual for some part of a day in each of 20 different weeks within the current or preceding calendar year. Employers subject to FUTA are automatically liable. Agricultural labor and domestic service coverage are addressed separately, and the state follows the federal thresholds—agricultural employers are liable when they pay $20,000 or more in wages in a quarter or employ 10 or more workers for 20 weeks; domestic employers are liable when they pay $1,000 or more in cash wages in a quarter. Non‑profit employers become liable when they employ four or more individuals for some part of a day in each of 20 weeks.
ui_threshold_weeks_text: 20 different weeks with at least one employee for general employers; 20 weeks with 10 or more workers for agricultural employers; 20 weeks with four or more workers for nonprofit employers.
withholding_threshold_description: Employers must register for a West Virginia withholding tax account with the State Tax Department and withhold state income tax on wages paid to employees; there is no minimum wage threshold—registration is required from the first payroll.
typical_processing_time: Employers must file an Employer’s Initial Statement (Form UC‑A‑154) when they meet liability conditions; WorkForce West Virginia typically assigns an unemployment account number within two to three weeks after receiving the application. The State Tax Department issues the withholding account number a few days after online registration.
required_information: Federal Employer Identification Number (FEIN)
Legal business name and trade name
Physical and mailing addresses and phone number
Type of business entity and date formed
Date employees first performed services in West Virginia and date first wages were paid
Total wages and number of employees
Names, titles, Social Security numbers and addresses of owners, partners, members or corporate officers
Business activity and NAICS code
Predecessor or successor business information
Payroll contact person and email
Whether the employer is agricultural, domestic or nonprofit.
filing_methods: Register for unemployment insurance by submitting the Employer’s Initial Statement (Form UC‑A‑154) online or by mail to WorkForce West Virginia
Register for employer withholding through the West Virginia State Tax Department’s MyTaxes online portal or by filing Form WV/BRT‑CNP
File quarterly wage reports and contributions electronically via the Employer Self‑Service portal and remit withholding tax through MyTaxes.
confirmation_proof: WorkForce West Virginia sends an employer account number and contribution rate notice once registration is processed; the State Tax Department issues a West Virginia withholding tax account number and permit.

contacts.phone: 304‑558‑2676 (WorkForce West Virginia Employer Status Determination Unit), 304‑558‑3333 (State Tax Department)

source_notes: The West Virginia Code defines an employer as any employing unit that pays wages of $1,500 or more in a calendar quarter or has at least one individual in employment for some part of a day in 20 different weeks during the current or preceding calendar year【870346139964908†L132-L136】.
